Neither of these props actually appeared in the stage production.<ref name="Dalek6388: Terry Nation's Daleks" >{{cite web |url=http://www.dalek6388.co.uk/terry-nations-daleks/ |title=Terry Nation's Daleks |last1=Green |first1=Jon |last2=Rymill |first2=Gavin |date=2011 |website=Dalek6388 |access-date=26 April 2011 }}</ref>
===''The Ultimate Adventure'' (1989)=== ''[[Doctor Who – The Ultimate Adventure]]'' was a stage play written by Terrance Dicks. It toured Great Britain, appearing at twenty theatres between April and August 1989.
Four blue/grey drones and a Black Dalek (credited as "The Chief Dalek") appeared in the play. Specific design differences from the television version of the time included a skirt section flared more to the sides and less to the front and rear, a single vertical column of hemispheres on the skirt side panels and a higher fender. The props had large, rectangular dome lights, a bottom neck ring which protruded beyond the shoulder line, and lacked both eye discs and slats. These Daleks also featured a dome that was a true hemisphere rather than the usual bevelled design and a single, oblong appendage box running across the front of the body.
A Dalek Emperor prop was also created, being a scaled-down but otherwise faithful reproduction of the version that appeared in ''[[The Evil of the Daleks]]'' with the addition of large wing-like structures to the sides. The Dalek props used in the production were built by the theatrical suppliers Suffolk Scenery.<ref name="Ultimate Dalek Builders" >{{cite web |url=http://www.theultimateadventure.co.uk/the-ultimate-adventure-daleks.html |title=The Daleks from The Ultimate Adventure |last=McCulloch |first=Gav |date=1989 |website=The Ultimate Adventure – Doctor Who Stageplay |publisher=theultimateadventure.co.uk |access-date=10 September 2009 }}</ref>
==Dalek variants in comics, books, audio dramas and video games== Various writers and artists have created new Dalek variants for media other than television, film and the theatre. The depiction of Daleks with coloured casings has also been used to indicate rank, although these differentiations do not constitute separate variants as such. Of particular note in this respect is [[John Peel (writer)|John Peel]]'s [[BBC Books]] ''Doctor Who'' novel ''[[War of the Daleks]]'' in which grey, blue, red, black and gold Daleks are described as having successively higher status, all serving under the [[#Dalek Prime|Dalek Prime]].<ref name="War of the Daleks" /> Other examples are the [[TV Century 21|''TV21'']] Dalek comic strip in which a Black Dalek is shown acting as second-in-command to the [[#Golden Emperor Dalek|Golden Emperor]], and [[Trevor Baxendale]]'s novel ''[[Prisoner of the Daleks]]'' where a Dalek Inquisitor General is described as being of the "New Series" design but having a casing of gunmetal black with gold slats and hemispheres.<ref name="Prisoner of the Daleks" >{{cite book |last=Baxendale |first=Trevor |authorlink=Trevor Baxendale |date=2009 |title=Doctor Who: [[Prisoner of the Daleks]] |series=[[New Series Adventures]] |number=33 |location=London |publisher=[[BBC Books]] |pages=182–183 |isbn=978-1-84607-641-1 }}</ref>
===Golden Emperor Dalek=== [[File:The_Golden_Emperor_Dalek.png|thumb|right|The Golden Emperor Dalek, as depicted by illustrator [[Ron Turner (illustrator)|Ron Turner]]]]The concept of an Emperor Dalek was first introduced in [[Dalek comic strips, illustrated annuals and graphic novels#The Dalek Book|''The Dalek Book'']] (1964),<ref name="The Dalek Book p8" >{{cite book |last1=Whitaker |first1=David |authorlink1=David Whitaker (screenwriter) |last2=Nation |first2=Terry |authorlink2=Terry Nation |date=1964 |title=[[Dalek comic strips, illustrated annuals and graphic novels#The Dalek Book|''The Dalek Book'']] |location=London |publisher=Panther Books Ltd. / Souvenir Press Ltd |page=8 }}</ref> re-appearing shortly thereafter in the [[TV Century 21|''TV21'']] comic strip [[Dalek comic strips, illustrated annuals and graphic novels#TV Century 21|''The Daleks'']] (1965 – 1967).<ref name="Altered Vistas – Doctorless Strips" >{{Cite web |url=http://www.alteredvistas.co.uk/html/doctorless.html |title=In The Comics – Doctorless Strips : TV Century 21 – The Daleks |last=Palmer |first=Stuart |date=2012 |website=Altered Vistas |access-date=19 September 2012 }}</ref>
In the comic strip version of events the planet Skaro was inhabited by two warring humanoid species; the tall, peaceful [[Thals]] and the aggressive blue-skinned Daleks. The Daleks build a [[neutron bomb]] to finally destroy the Thals and bring the conflict to an end. A [[meteorite]] storm causes the device to detonate prematurely, devastating Skaro and the planet's civilisations. The only survivors of the Dalek race are the scientist Yarvelling and the warlord Zolfian. While exploring the shattered remains of their world they are attacked, and then interrogated, by a prototype war machine which Yarvelling had created shortly before the holocaust. It is implied that these machines were intended to act as semi-autonomous robotic warriors. It informs them that it is actually a mutated Dalek, the result of radiation from the neutron bomb explosion, which has commandeered the casing to use as a travel machine. It says that there are many more mutants and persuades Yarvelling and Zolfian to build more casings to house them. Before the last two humanoid Daleks die, exhausted by their labours and the effects of radiation, it appoints itself as Emperor and has a special casing constructed to reflect its new rank, made from "...Flidor gold, Quartz and Arkellis flower sap...".<ref name="Genesis of Evil" /> The Golden Emperor is usually depicted as being slightly shorter than a standard Dalek with a disproportionately large spherical head section.
The title page of ''The Dalek Book'' lists three contributing illustrators; [[Richard E. Jennings|Richard Jennings]], John Woods and A.B. Cornwell. As none of the stories are individually credited it is uncertain which artist or artists first developed the Golden Emperor design. Two illustrators provided interpretations of the Golden Emperor for the ''TV21'' comic strip; Jennings again, and [[Ron Turner (illustrator)|Ron Turner]] who superseded him in later instalments.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Russell |first=Gary |date=4 August 1994 |title=The Dalek Chronicles Found! |journal=[[Doctor Who Magazine]] |issue=Summer Special: The Dalek Chronicles |page=2 |location=Royal Tunbridge Wells |publisher=[[Marvel UK]] |editor1-first=Russell |editor1-last=Gary |editor1-link=Gary Russell |issn=1353-7628 }}</ref>
==="The Dalek Book" Daleks=== ''The Dalek Book'' (1964) is notable, although not unique, in portraying a Dalek variant which has a "speaker grille" set centrally on the chest and, occasionally, a stylised numeral on the dome. Neither of these items has ever been incorporated in a Dalek variant shown on-screen.
During rehearsals for the first ''Doctor Who'' serial in which they appeared a numbered piece of card was taped to the dome of each Dalek prop to assist the director in distinguishing them, with a tape roll being wedged behind the top front collar for safekeeping.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Peel |first1=John |authorlink1=John Peel (writer) |last2=Nation |first2=Terry |authorlink2=Terry Nation |date=1988 |title=The Official Doctor Who & the Daleks Book |location=New York |publisher=[[St. Martin's Press]] |page=19 |isbn=0-312-02264-6 }}</ref> These objects subsequently appeared in reference photographs of the Daleks provided by the BBC to merchandise producers, with the illustrators of ''The Dalek Book'' interpreting them as speaker grilles and insignia.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Hearn |first=Marcus |date=23 November 2011 |title=The Dalek Chronicles |journal=[[SFX Magazine]] Collection |volume=2 |issue=Doctor Who: The Fanzine |page=124 |location=Bath |publisher=[[Future Publishing Ltd]] |isbn=1-85870-445-6 }}</ref> Shortly after the publication of this volume other merchandise and packaging appeared featuring Daleks with the speaker grille design element. These included Dalek board games, [[bagatelle]], "Cutta-Mastic" [[polystyrene]] sculpting sets, [[Labyrinth (marble game)|marble mazes]] and a ray gun torch.<ref name="Richard's Memorabilia Collection" >{{cite web |url=http://www.richardwho.co.uk/collectors/vuser/index.asp?u=26 |title=Doctor Who Collectors: Richard in Essex |date=2009 |website=www.richardwho.com |access-date=18 September 2009 }}</ref>
===Dalek Emperor=== A Dalek Emperor, described as being similar that seen in ''[[The Evil of the Daleks]]'', appears in the [[Telos Doctor Who novellas|Telos novella]] ''[[The Dalek Factor]]'' (2004) by [[Simon Clark (novelist)|Simon Clark]]. It is referred to as "an Emperor", implying there is more than one during the period in which the story is set.<ref name="The Dalek Factor" >{{cite book |last=Clark |first=Simon |authorlink=Simon Clark (novelist) |date=2004 |title=[[The Dalek Factor]] |series=[[Telos Doctor Who novellas]] |number=15 |location=Prestatyn |publisher=[[Telos Publishing]] |isbn=1-903889-30-8 }}</ref>
===Dalek Prime=== A Dalek Prime is referred to in several of the novels based on ''Doctor Who'' serials (''[[The Chase (Doctor Who)#In print|The Chase]]'', ''[[The Daleks' Master Plan#In print|The Daleks' Master Plan]]'', ''[[The Power of the Daleks#In print|The Power of the Daleks]]'', ''[[The Evil of the Daleks#In print|The Evil of the Daleks]]''). It is also mentioned in John Peel's [[Eighth Doctor]] novels, ''[[War of the Daleks]]'' (1997)<ref name="War of the Daleks" /> and ''[[Legacy of the Daleks]]'' (1998).<ref name="Legacy of the Daleks" >{{cite book |last=Peel |first=John |authorlink=John Peel (writer) |date=1998 |title=[[Legacy of the Daleks]] |series=[[Eighth Doctor Adventures]] |number=10 |location=London |publisher=[[BBC Books]] |isbn=0-563-40574-0 }}</ref> Although portrayed as being a leader its precise position in the Dalek hierarchy is not made clear. In ''War of the Daleks'' its description closely matches that of the [[#Golden Emperor Dalek|''TV21'' Golden Emperor]].
===Dalek Time Controller=== The Dalek Time Controller features in the [[Big Finish Productions]] Doctor Who audio dramas ''[[Patient Zero (audio drama)|Patient Zero]]'' (2009), ''[[Lucie Miller / To the Death (audio drama)|Lucie Miller]]'' (2011), ''[[Lucie Miller / To the Death (audio drama)|To the Death]]'' (2011), ''[[Dark Eyes (audio drama)|Dark Eyes]]'' (2012), ''[[Dark Eyes 2]]'' (2014), ''[[Dark Eyes 4]]'' (2015) and the novel ''[[The Dalek Generation]]'' (2013). It is portrayed as being genetically engineered to have an enhanced perception of the space-time vortex, enabling it to direct Dalek strategies involving time travel while limiting temporal destabilisation. The novel describes it as the ultimate form of Dalek life, able to command even the Dalek Supreme, and having a neck bin encircled by diagonally revolving rings of vortex energy.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Briggs |first1=Nicholas |authorlink1=Nicholas Briggs |date=2013 |title=[[The Dalek Generation]] |series=[[New Series Adventures]] |number=50 |location=London |publisher=[[BBC Books]] |pages=25, 184 |isbn=978-1-84990-575-6 }}</ref> The Dalek Time Controller is voiced in the audio productions by actor [[Nicholas Briggs]].
==="Hayakawa" Daleks=== [[Image:Japanese Dalek.jpg|left|thumb|alt=A truncated cone adorned with two encircling rows of small oval markings in a zigzag pattern, topped by a dome and with a large inverted hemisphere for a base. To one side of the cone is attached a device resembling a machine gun and to the other a rod terminating in a group of four spherical objects. Another rod projects from a vertical slot in the front of the dome, terminating in a disc-shaped eyeball.|"Hayakawa" Dalek variant.]]
Four of the [[Target Books]] ''Doctor Who'' serial novelisations were translated into Japanese by Yukio Sekiguchi and published in 1980 by Hayakawa Bunko books. These included [[The Daleks#In print|Doctor Who and the Daleks]] as {{nihongo|''Jikuu Daikettou!''|時空大血闘!||lit. "Big Bloody Space-Time Battle!"}}<ref name="Jikuu Daikettou!" >{{cite book |last=Sekiguchi |first=Yukio |date=1980 |title=Jikuu Daikettou! ( 時空大血闘! ) |trans-title=Doctor Who & the Daleks |language=Japanese |location=Tokyo |publisher=Hayakawa Bunko }}</ref> and [[Day of the Daleks#In print|Doctor Who and the Day of the Daleks]] as {{nihongo|''Dareku – Zoku no Gyakushuu!''|ダレク – 族の逆襲!||lit. "Dalek – The Race's Counterattack!"}}<ref name="Dareku - Zoku no Gyakushuu!" >{{cite book |last=Sekiguchi |first=Yukio |date=1980 |title=Dareku – Zoku No Gyakushuu! ( ダレク – 族の逆襲! ) |trans-title=Doctor Who & the Day of the Daleks |language=Japanese |location=Tokyo |publisher=Hayakawa Bunko }}</ref> Artist Michiaki Sato was commissioned to provide illustrations for these volumes.
Unlike other comic book and graphic artists whose work, however stylised, usually presents relatively minor variations to the standard Dalek form, Sato's renderings show a unique Dalek variant which is a radical departure from the recognised design. Possible reasons for this include lack of access to source material, the Japanese publishers having no rights to the use of the Dalek image and the artist simply being allowed the free rein of his imagination.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://home.netspeed.com.au/reguli/DALEKMIT.htm |title=The Daleks: Mitsubishi Daleks |last=White |first=Nikki |date=1989 |website=The Ensovaari Embassy |access-date=7 July 2009 }}</ref>
===Marine Daleks=== Marine Daleks, introduced in the novel ''[[War of the Daleks]]'' (1997), are [[torpedo]]-shaped with their eye at the front and have a gun stick and grappling arm parallel to their body. They are stated to be larger than standard Daleks.<ref name="War of the Daleks" />
===Marsh Daleks=== [[Image:Marsh Dalek.jpg|thumb|alt=A truncated cone, bisected by a flange one quarter way up its length, topped by a dome and standing on two jointed leg struts which emerge from a flat base. On the front of the cone are two parallel vertical slots, between which a gun stick is mounted below a single hemisphere. A standard Dalek eye protrudes from the dome.|A Marsh Dalek from ''The Dalek Book''.]]
The 1964 ''The Dalek Book'' story ''The Monsters of Gurnian'', written by Terry Nation and David Whittaker, features bipedal Marsh Daleks which are used to keep in check the Horrorkons; two headed [[plesiosaur]]-like creatures which inhabit the swamps of the planet Gurnian.<ref name="The Dalek Book p73 & 74" >{{cite book |last1=Whitaker |first1=David |authorlink1=David Whitaker (screenwriter) |last2=Nation |first2=Terry |authorlink2=Terry Nation |date=1964 |title=[[Dalek comic strips, illustrated annuals and graphic novels#The Dalek Book|''The Dalek Book'']] |location=London |publisher=[[Panther Books]] / Souvenir Press Ltd |pages=73–74 }}</ref> As none of the stories or artwork in the book are individually credited it is unknown which of the contributing artists developed the Marsh Dalek design. Marsh Daleks are also referenced briefly in [[Marc Platt (writer)|Marc Platt's]] ''Doctor Who'' novel ''[[Lungbarrow]]'' (1997), in which it is said that during the 26th century humans fought and disabled them by shooting at their legs with high-impulse [[carbine]]s.<ref name="Lungbarrow" >{{cite book |last=Platt |first=Marc |authorlink=Marc Platt (writer) |date=1997 |title=[[Lungbarrow]] |series=[[Virgin New Adventures]] |number=60 |location=London |publisher=[[Virgin Books]] |isbn=0-426-20502-2 }}</ref>
===Predator Dalek=== The Predator Dalek features in the Doctor Who novel ''[[Engines of War (Doctor Who)|Engines of War]]'' (2014), written by [[George Mann (writer)|George Mann]]. It is stated to be a prototype created to make a perfect Dalek during [[Time War (Doctor Who)|The Last Great Time War]]. This is to be accomplished by capturing the [[War Doctor]], removing his memory and emotions to leave only his creativity, and then integrating him with its technology. It is described as being of the standard [[#"New Series" Daleks|"New Series" Dalek]] design but twice as large, with a deep, metallic vermillion skirt and black hemispheres. The plan is foiled when the Predator Dalek is destroyed, together with the Dalek fleet, by the War Doctor and the Time Lord [[List of Doctor Who villains#Borusa|Borusa]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Mann |first1=George |authorlink1=George Mann (writer) |date=2014 |title= Doctor Who: Engines of War |location=London |publisher=[[BBC Books]] |page=291 |isbn=978-1-84990-848-1 }}</ref>
===Psyche Daleks=== Appearing briefly in the comic strip ''[[Emperor of the Daleks]]'' (1993), written by [[John Freeman (editor)|John Freeman]] and [[Paul Cornell]], Psyche Daleks are depicted with a large mass of green brain tissue contained within a transparent sphere that sits on top of the shoulder section in place of the normal neck bin and dome. In the story a Psyche Dalek is used to control a small group of partially robotised prisoners through a remote device mounted on its arm in place of a plunger. The comic strip was drawn by [[Lee Sullivan (comics)|Lee Sullivan]].<ref name="Emperor of the Daleks" >{{cite comic |writer=[[Paul Cornell|Cornell, Paul]] |artist=[[Lee Sullivan (comics)|Sullivan, Lee]] |colorist=Marina Graham |letterer=[[Annie Parkhouse|Annie Halfacree]] |editor=[[John Freeman (editor)|Freeman, John]] |story=[[Emperor of the Daleks]] |title=[[Doctor Who Magazine]] |issue=197–202 |date=1993 |publisher=[[Marvel UK]] |location=London |id=ISSN 0957-9818 }}</ref>
===Scout Daleks=== In Ben Aaronovitch's novelisation of ''[[Remembrance of the Daleks#In print|Remembrance of the Daleks]]'' (1990) the Imperial Dalek faction use Scout Daleks which are described as being more powerful and streamlined than standard Daleks.<ref name=" Remembrance of the Daleks Novel" />
===Spider Daleks=== Spider Daleks were a variant proposed by [[John Leekley]] for an aborted ''Doctor Who'' television movie to be produced by [[Amblin Entertainment]] in 1994.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Segal |first1=Philip |authorlink1=Philip Segal |last2=Russell |first2=Gary |authorlink2=Gary Russell |date=2000 |title=Doctor Who: Regeneration |location=London |publisher=[[HarperCollins]] |isbn=0-00-710591-6 }}</ref> Spider Daleks directly based on the Amblin production concept sketches were eventually used in the comic strip [[Dalek comic strips, illustrated annuals and graphic novels#Fire and Brimstone|''Fire and Brimstone'']] (1997) in which they are presented as a radically different form of Dalek from a [[Multiverse|parallel universe]]. The strip was drawn by [[Martin Geraghty]] and [[Robin Smith (comics)|Robin Smith]].<ref>{{cite comic |writer=[[Alan Barnes (writer)|Barnes, Alan]] |penciller=[[Martin Geraghty|Geraghty, Martin]] |inker=[[Robin Smith (comics)|Smith, Robin]] |letterer=Elitta Fell |editor=Gillatt, Gary |story=[[Dalek comic strips, illustrated annuals and graphic novels#Fire and Brimstone|''Fire and Brimstone'']] |title=[[Doctor Who Magazine]] |issue=251–255 |date=1997 |publisher=[[Marvel UK]] |location=London |id=ISSN 0957-9818 }}</ref> In John Peel's novel ''[[War of the Daleks]]'' (1997) they are depicted as creations of Davros and described as being slightly larger than a standard Dalek, with eight legs emerging from the lower half. They are said to have greater manoeuvrability than standard Daleks, at the cost of being more vulnerable at their joints.<ref name="War of the Daleks" />
===Strider Daleks=== Giant versions of the Spider Dalek, known as Striders, are mentioned in John Peel's novel ''[[War of the Daleks]]'' (1997). They are said to be ten times larger than a standard Spider Dalek and equipped with additional weapons.<ref name="War of the Daleks" />
===The Klade=== The Klade are a people from the distant future in [[Lance Parkin]]'s BBC [[Eighth Doctor]] novel ''[[Father Time (Doctor Who)|Father Time]]'' (2001) and the [[Miranda (Doctor Who)|Miranda]] spin-off comics (2003). Although physically humanoid they share many cultural characteristics with the Daleks and appear to regard Dalek history as their own. Their name is both an anagram of "Dalek", as "Dalek" is itself of "[[History of the Daleks#Origins|Kaled]]" and a play on the biological term "[[clade]]", being a group of species sharing a common ancestor. They are "...the super-evolved descendants of the Daleks",<ref>{{cite book |last1=Parkin |first1=Lance |authorlink1=Lance Parkin |last2=Pearson |first2=Lars |authorlink2=Lars Pearson |date=2007 |title=AHistory: An Unauthorized History of the Doctor Who Universe |edition=2nd |location=Des Moines |publisher=[[Mad Norwegian Press]] |page=372 |isbn=978-0-975944-66-0 }}</ref> the implication being that, like the [[Thals]], their mutation has come "full circle" and returned them to a humanoid form.
===Skaro Degradations=== The Skaro Degradations are first mentioned in the Doctor Who television serial ''[[The End of Time (Doctor Who)|The End of Time]]'' (2009), where the [[Tenth Doctor]] says they were one of the horrors of [[Time War (Doctor Who)|The Last Great Time War]]. They later appear in the [[War Doctor]] novel ''[[Engines of War (Doctor Who)|Engines of War]]'' (2014) by George Mann, described as being unstable and unpredictable abominations created by Dalek experiments to retro-evolve their own genome. Three types are mentioned in the book. Glider Degradations travel by hovering above the ground. The Dalek mutant is housed in a clear, reinforced compartment set beneath a standard Dalek dome and resembles a limbless, humanoid torso. Mechanical arms and energy weapons are located on both sides of the casing. Spider Degradations are egg-shaped with red and black hemispheres, move on three legs and are armed with four energy weapons. Temporal Weapon Degradations are similar to [[#Special Weapons Dalek|Special Weapons Daleks]] and equipped with a temporal cannon capable of erasing its victims from history.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Mann |first1=George |authorlink1=George Mann (writer) |date=2014 |title= Doctor Who: Engines of War |location=London |publisher=[[BBC Books]] |isbn=978-1-84990-848-1 }}</ref>
===Alternate timeline Daleks=== Daleks from an [[alternate timeline]] appear in the [[E-book]] ''The Ripple Effect'' (2013) by [[Malorie Blackman]]. The alternate Daleks are portrayed as a civilised, philosophical, peace-loving race, speaking with quiet, modulated voices and having individual names. Most of the alternate Daleks have two manipulator arms and no weapon, with only those defending Skaro from space being armed. Ultimately the Doctor discovers that the alternate timeline is unstable, causing the Universe to decay. Travelling back in time he restores the original timeline, erasing the alternate Daleks from existence.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Blackman |first1=Malorie |authorlink1=Malorie Blackman |date=2013 |title= The Ripple Effect |series=Doctor Who 50th Anniversary ebooks |number=7 |location=London |publisher=[[Puffin]] |asin= B00B5N35JY }}</ref>
===Stained Glass Daleks=== [[Stained Glass]] Daleks feature in the [[Big Finish Productions]] Doctor Who audio drama ''Order of the Daleks'' (2016).<ref name="Order of the Daleks" >{{cite AV media |people=[[Mike Tucker]] (writer), [[Jamie Anderson (producer)|Jamie Anderson]] (director), David Richardson (producer) |date=November 2016 |id=218 |title=''Order of the Daleks'' |medium=CD |location= Berkshire |publisher=[[Big Finish Productions]] |isbn=978-1-78178-897-4 }}</ref> They are depicted as having ornate, stained glass casings and are harboured by monks of the Brotherhood of the Black Petal on the technologically undeveloped planet Strellin. The Stained Glass Dalek concept was created by [[Mike Tucker]], with the cover artwork for the audio production being designed and rendered by Chris Thompson.<ref name="Designing the Stained Glass Dalek" >{{cite web |url= http://www.jamieanderson.me.uk/designing-stained-glass-dalek/ |title=Designing the Stained Glass Dalek |date=August 2016 |website=Jamie Anderson |publisher=[[Jamie Anderson (producer)|Jamie Anderson]] |access-date=6 November 2016 }}</ref>
===New Paradigm Dalek Emperor=== Appearing at the climax of "City of the Daleks" (2010), the first instalment of the video game [[Doctor Who: The Adventure Games]], the New Paradigm Dalek Emperor is almost identical to the [[#Emperor Dalek|New Series Emperor Dalek]] seen in the 2005 episode [[The Parting of the Ways]]. Notable differences are the dome and eye assembly, which are of the [[#New Paradigm Daleks|New Paradigm]] design, and a blue colour scheme.<ref name="City of the Daleks" >{{cite video game |title=[[Doctor Who: The Adventure Games#City of the Daleks|City of the Daleks]] |developer=[[Sumo Digital]] |publisher=BBC Wales Interactive |date=5 June 2010 |platform=[[Microsoft Windows]], [[Mac OS]] |version=1.0 }}</ref>
===The Eternity Clock Dalek Emperor=== Featured in the video game [[Doctor Who: The Eternity Clock]] (2012), this version of the Dalek Emperor first appears as a large, levitating, purple sphere, studded with silver hemispheres. This is shown to be a shell which can expand and split into sixteen vertical segments, positionable to form a defensive barrier. The internal structure is mainly of the [[#New Paradigm Daleks|New Paradigm]] design, consisting of a large dome incorporating a foreshortened eye stalk and thin, extended dome lights, supported by an inverted neck bin. Below this a conical metallic structure tapers downward towards a circular, rotating weapons platform to which it is connected by an energy field. Arranged evenly around the edge of the platform are three [[#"New Series" Daleks'|"New Series" Dalek]] style gun sticks.<ref name="The Eternity Clock" >{{cite video game |title=[[Doctor Who: The Eternity Clock]] |developer=[[Supermassive Games]] |publisher=[[BBC Worldwide]] |date= 2012 |platform=[[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 3]], [[PlayStation Vita]] |version=1.0 }}</ref>
==Other notable Dalek designs==
===The Dark Dimension Dalek=== "[[List of unmade Doctor Who serials and films#Lost in the Dark Dimension|Lost in the Dark Dimension]]" was the working title of a feature-length BBC ''Doctor Who'' episode, planned to celebrate the programme's thirtieth anniversary.<ref name="Lost in The Dark Dimension Article" >{{cite journal |last=Norton |first=Charles |date=21 January 2010 |title=Doctor Who: Lost in The Dark Dimension |journal=[[SciFiNow]] Magazine |issue=37 |pages=34–37 |location=Bournemouth |publisher=[[Imagine Publishing]] |issn=1477-6650 }}</ref> Chris Fitzgerald at [[Jim Henson's Creature Shop]] was engaged to redesign the [[#Special Weapons Dalek|Special Weapons Dalek]] for the production.<ref name="Dark Dimension Article">{{cite web |url=http://nzdwfc.tetrap.com/archive/tsv44/darkdimension.html |title=TSV 44: Inside the Dark Dimension |last=Preddle |first=Jon |date=1995 |website=archive.is - nzdwfc.tetrap.com |access-date=12 December 2017 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://archive.fo/20120713220042/http://nzdwfc.tetrap.com/archive/tsv44/darkdimension.html |archivedate=13 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> A sketch of the proposed variant was produced at the time by BBC artist Alan Marshall. Notable differences from a standard Dalek include a substantially enlarged fender, an enhanced midsection featuring two large shoulder-mounted cannon and a foreshortened neck bin encircled by three thick neck rings. Programme development commenced in June 1992 and was officially cancelled in July 1993, with the BBC citing financial and logistical reasons.<ref name="Illuminating the Dark Dimension" >{{cite journal |last=Bignell |first=Richard |date=16 January 2012 |title=Illuminating the Dark Dimension |journal=Nothing at the End of the Lane |issue=3 |page=112 |location=Chatham |publisher=Nothing at the End of the Lane }}</ref> Although a Dark Dimension Dalek prop was never constructed by the BBC it has become the subject of a number of illustrations and a full size version built by a fan.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.projectdalek.co.uk/storm/ |title=Dalek STORM The Dark Dimensions Special Weapons Dalek |last=Clark |first=Alan |date=2009 |website=Dalek Storm |accessdate=20 December 2015 }}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Doctor Who|BBC|Science fiction}} *[[Dalek]] *[[History of the Daleks]] *[[Dalek comic strips, illustrated annuals and graphic novels]] *[[Cult of Skaro]] *[[Davros]] *[[Skaro]]

==External links== {{Commons category|Daleks}} {{Wiktionary|Dalek}} {{Wikiquote|The_Daleks|The Daleks}} *[https://tardis.wikia.com/wiki/Dalek_variants Dalek variants] – List of Dalek variants at [https://tardis.wikia.com/wiki/Doctor_Who_Wiki TARDIS Data Core], an external wiki. *[http://www.dalek6388.co.uk/ Dalek 6388] – A comprehensive serial-by-serial guide to Dalek variants and the Dalek props. *[http://www.dalekplanet.com/ Dalek Planet] – Illustrations of Dalek variants with a design/colour guide. *[http://jimsdaleksite.myfreesites.net/ Jim's Dalek Site] – CGI versions of Dalek variants, including those seen in the classic Doctor Who series and the two feature films. *[http://www.thedoctorwhosite.co.uk/dalek/types/ The Doctor Who Site: Dalek Types] – Dalek colour schemes and hierarchy. *[http://www.projectdalek.co.uk/files/index.html Project Dalek] – Dalek variant plans and reference material. *[http://www.themindrobber.co.uk/dalek-types-drone-leader-supreme.html The Mind Robber: Dalek Spotter's Guide] – Illustrations of the Dalek types and colour schemes shown in Doctor Who. *[http://www.theultimateadventure.co.uk/ The Ultimate Adventure] – The Ultimate Adventure stage play website. *[http://www.alteredvistas.co.uk/html/doctorless.html Altered Vistas: In the Comics – Doctorless Strips] – Detailed listing of Dalek comic book appearances. *[https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/profiles/5MWZlD6W83HX07sDNn8ttkp/the-daleks BBC Doctor Who Website: The Daleks] – Photo galleries and video clips of major Dalek appearances and variants from 1963 to the present day.

page.title: Death and legacy of Tom Thomson

revision.text:
{{About|the controversy surrounding President Allende's death|the coup that brought Army Commander-in-Chief [[Augusto Pinochet]] to power|1973 Chilean coup d'état}} [[File:Lentes Salvador Allende.jpg|thumb|Allende's glasses, found in the Palacio de La Moneda after his death.]] On September 11, 1973, [[Salvador Allende]], [[President of Chile]], died of self-inflicted gunshot wounds during a [[1973 Chilean coup d'état|coup d'état]] led by the [[Chilean Army]] Commander-in-Chief [[Augusto Pinochet]]. After decades of suspicions that Allende might have been assassinated by the [[Military of Chile|Chilean Armed Forces]], a Chilean court in 2011 authorized the exhumation and autopsy of Allende's remains. A team of international experts examined the remains and concluded that Allende had shot himself with an [[AK-47]] [[assault rifle]].{{cite web |url=http://www.lanacion.cl/fueron-exhumados-los-restos-de-salvador-allende/noticias/2011-05-23/085914.html |title=nacion.cl - Restos de Salvador Allende fueron exhumados |publisher=Lanacion.cl |date=2011-05-23 |accessdate=2012-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218154958/http://www.lanacion.cl/fueron-exhumados-los-restos-de-salvador-allende/noticias/2011-05-23/085914.html |archivedate=2014-12-18 |df= }} In December 2011, the judge in charge of the investigation affirmed the experts' findings and ruled Allende's death a suicide.{{cite web|url=http://noticias.terra.com.co/internacional/latinoamerica/ministro-cierra-investigacion-sobre-allende-se-suicido,3b5fd07709b84310VgnVCM20000099f154d0RCRD.html |title=Ministro cierra investigación sobre Allende: se suicidó - Terra Colombia |publisher=Noticias.terra.com.co |accessdate=2012-09-12}} On September 11, 2012, the 39th anniversary of Allende's death, a Chilean appeals court unanimously upheld the trial court's ruling, officially closing the case.{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/09/11/world/americas/chile-allende-suicide/index.html |title=Chilean court confirms Allende suicide - CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |accessdate=2012-09-12}} According to [[Isabel Allende Bussi]]—the daughter of Salvador Allende and currently a member of the [[Senate of Chile|Chilean Senate]]—the Allende family has long accepted that the former President shot himself, telling the BBC that: "The report conclusions are consistent with what we already believed. When faced with extreme circumstances, he made the decision of taking his own life, instead of being humiliated."{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-14210729 |title=BBC News - Chile inquiry confirms President Allende killed himself |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2011-07-19 |accessdate=2012-09-12}} ==Death== On September 11, 1973, just prior to the capture of the [[Palacio de La Moneda]] (the presidential palace) by military units loyal to Pinochet, President Salvador Allende made his famous [[s:Salvador Allende's Last Speech|farewell speech]] to Chileans on live radio (''Radio Magallanes''). The president spoke of his love for Chile and of his deep faith in its future. He also stated that, as he was committed to Chile, he would not take an easy way out or be used as a propaganda tool by those he called "traitors" (accepting an offer of safe passage, like [[Carlos Altamirano]]). The radio address was made while gunfire and explosions were clearly audible in the background.{{Cite web|title = ultimos discursos de allende Archives - piensaChile ★ piensachile.com|url = http://piensachile.com/tag/ultimos-discursos-de-allende/|website = piensachile.com|accessdate = 2015-09-11}} Shortly afterwards, an official announcement declared that he had gone to war with an [[AK-47]] rifle.{{cite web |url=http://www.presidencia.gob.cl/view/viewGaleriaPresidentes.asp?id=31&seccion=Presidencia%20por%20Dentro&interfazseccion=Galeria%20Presidentes#a31 |title=Salvador Allende Gossens |publisher=Presidencia de la República de Chile |accessdate=2006-04-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040811031934/http://www.presidencia.gob.cl/view/viewGaleriaPresidentes.asp?id=31&seccion=Presidencia%20por%20Dentro&interfazseccion=Galeria%20Presidentes#a31 |archivedate=2004-08-11 |df= }} Allende's corpse was carried out of Palacio de La Moneda wrapped in a [[Bolivia]]n [[poncho]] by soldiers and fire fighters.González 2013, p. 21. His body was sent to [[List of hospitals in Chile|Hospital Militar]] arriving about 17:30. Among those present during the autopsy was one of Allende's former classmates in university.González 2013, p. 22. The autopsy also recorded his death as a suicide.Gonzalez Camus, Ignacio, ''El dia en que murio Allende'' ("The day that Allende Died"), 1988, pp. 282 and following. Allende's weapon was purportedly given to him as a gift by [[Fidel Castro]]. It bore a golden plate engraved: "To my good friend Salvador from Fidel, who by different means tries to achieve the same goals".Whelan, James, ''Out of the Ashes: The Life, Death and Transfiguration of Democracy in Chile'', 1989, pp. 511-512 and 519-520. ==Official version== At approximately 1:50 PM local time, President Allende ordered the defenders of the La Moneda Palace to surrender. The defenders then formed a line from the second floor, down the stairs and onto the Morande street door. The president went along this queue, from the ground floor up the stairs, shaking hands and thanking everyone personally for their support in that difficult moment. At the end of the queue, Allende turned toward the Independence salon, located in the north-east side of the Palace's second floor. At the same time, Dr. Patricio Guijón (a member of La Moneda's infirmary staff) himself decided to return upstairs to recover his gas-mask as a souvenir. He heard a noise, and opened the door of the Independence salon in time to see the president shoot himself with his [[AK-47]].[https://www.nytimes.com/1988/09/02/world/chile-ends-exile-of-allende-family.html CHILE ENDS EXILE OF ALLENDE FAMILY], ''The New York Times'', 2 September 1988. Accessed online 30 June 2008. From the other side of the salon and through an open door, Dr. José Quiroga,Patricio Zamorano, [http://www.laopinion.com/archivo/index.html?START=1&RESULTSTART=1&DISPLAYTYPE=single&FREETEXT=quiroga&FDATEd12=&FDATEd13=&SORT_MODE=SORT_MODE Muerte de Allende: los testigos que quedaron fuera de la historia] {{es icon}}, ''La Opinión Digital'', 11 September 2003. Accessed online 22 September 2006. Arsenio Poupin, a member of the cabinet, Enrique Huerta, a palace functionary, two detectives from the Presidential security detail, and some GAPs (Presidential Security) were able to see the moment of death, or arrive a few seconds afterwards, attracted by the noise. {| class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 85%; background:#c6dbf7; color:black; width:30em; max-width: 40%;" cellspacing="5" | style="text-align: left;" |"Workers of my country, I have faith in Chile and its destiny. Other men will overcome this dark and bitter moment when treason seeks to prevail. Keep in mind that, much sooner than later, the great avenues will again be opened through which will pass free men to construct a better society. Long live Chile! Long live the people! Long live the workers!" |- | style="text-align: left;" | '''''President Salvador Allende's farewell speech,'''
September 11, 1973.''{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Salvador_Allende%27s_Last_Speech |title=Salvador Allende's Last Speech - Wikisource, the free online library |publisher=En.wikisource.org |accessdate=2012-09-12}} |} ===Witnesses=== All sources seem to agree that at least the following witnesses were present: *Dr. Patricio Guijón – member of the Presidential Medical Staff – ''Survived'' *Dr. José Quiroga – member of the Presidential Medical Staff – ''Survived'' *Arsenio Poupin Oissel – Presidential Advisor and member of the cabinet – ''Executed a few days later'' *Enrique Huerta Corvalán – Palace Intendant (governor) – ''Executed a few days later'' *David Garrido – Detective (Presidential Security Detail) – ''Survived'' *Ricardo Pincheira – Detective (Presidential Security Detail) – ''Survived'' *Pablo Manuel Zepeda Camillieri – GAP (Presidential Security) – ''Survived'' Of these witnesses, only Dr. Guijón spoke about the events immediately after they happened, and was roundly vilified for doing so. Some sources misattribute Guijón's declarations to "Allende's personal doctor", Enrique Paris Roa, who was at La Moneda not in his professional role but as a member of Allende's cabinet. He does not appear to have made any such statement as he was executed shortly afterwards.Anne-Marie O'Connor, [http://www.oberlin.edu/faculty/svolk/lat102200.htm Out of the Ashes], ''Los Angeles Times'' 22 October 2000. Reproduced online on the site of [[Oberlin College]] professor Steven S. Volk, accessed 22 September 2006. The other witnesses kept silent until after the restoration of democracy in Chile, as they believed (according to their own statements) that to corroborate the version of a suicide would in some measure downgrade Allende's sacrifice and lend support to the military regime. Of the two doctors from the Moneda Palace infirmary who witnessed the suicide, Patricio Guijón made a statement at the time. However, Dr. [[José Quiroga]] only confirmed the details in 1999.Pape, Eric, [http://www.garella.com/rich/eric/exile.htm Five Degrees of Exile], ''[[Los Angeles Times]] Magazine'', 11 July 1999. Reproduced online as part of [http://www.garella.com/rich/eric/clips.htm an archive of Pape's articles], accessed 22 September 2006. ==Controversy== During the subsequent years of the [[Military dictatorship of Chile (1973–90)|Pinochet regime]], there existed a legitimate controversy about whether plotters of the coup d'état had assassinated Allende. The definitive finding of suicide by international experts and the Chilean courts in 2011 seems to have put the controversy to rest. Almost all claims of an ongoing "controversy" regarding Allende's death seem to predate the 2011 investigations and the factual record left in its wake. [[Fidel Castro]], who had given President Allende the AK-47 used as the suicide weapon, provides an example of the speculation and political posturing that grew out of Allende's death and the Pinochet coup d'état. On 28 September 1973 (only two weeks after Allende's death), Castro told a Cuban crowd in [[Havana]]'s ''Plaza de la Revolución'' that Allende had died in [[Palacio de La Moneda|La Moneda]] wrapped in a Chilean flag, firing at Pinochet troops with Fidel's rifle. Over the coming decades, the Cuban leader would continue to make public addresses using this version of events. Castro's public statements formed the basis of Robinson Rojas' 1975 book ''The murder of Allende and the end of the Chilean way to socialism''. Rojas asserted that the Chilean president had been killed by Pinochet's military forces while defending the palace.Rojas, Robinson (1985). ''The Murder of Allende and the End of the Chilean Way to Socialism''. Joanna Cotler Books. With the [[Chilean transition to democracy|peaceful transition to democracy]] in Chile in 1990, the view that Allende committed suicide began to gain popular acceptance as different testimonies confirming the details of the suicide have become available in press and in documentary interviews. Likewise, members of Allende's immediate family including his wife and his daughter, have never disputed that it was a suicide.{{cite web |url=http://www.estadao.com.br/internacional/not_int239424,0.htm |title=''EUA tentaram impedir posse de Allende, diz documento.'' Washington: Associated Press-Agência Estado, ''in'' ''O Estado de S. Paulo'', september 10, 2008, 15:56 |publisher=Estadao.com.br |accessdate=2012-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090227111108/http://www.estadao.com.br/internacional/not_int239424%2C0.htm |archivedate=2009-02-27 |df= }} A further example of pre-2011 controversializing is found in Chilean doctor Luis Ravanal's 2008 article published in the magazine ''El Periodista'' stating that Allende's wounds were "not compatible" with suicide. Asked to comment on Dr. Ravanal's hypothesis, the Chilean congresswoman [[Isabel Allende (politician)|Isabel Allende]], the President's daughter, said that the suicide version is the correct one.{{cite web |url=http://www2.eluniversal.com.mx/pls/impreso/noticia.html?id_nota=164983&tabla=notas |title=Admite hija de Allende suicidio de su padre |date=August 17, 2003 |publisher=[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]] |location=Mexico City, Mexico |language=Spanish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121014043246/http://www2.eluniversal.com.mx/pls/impreso/noticia.html?id_nota=164983&tabla=notas |archivedate=October 14, 2012 |df= }} In late January 2011, a Chilean judge opened an investigation into the death of Salvador Allende together with hundreds of other possible human rights abuses committed during the 1973 coup that brought Augusto Pinochet to power.{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/28/world/americas/28chile.html | title = Chilean Judge Orders Investigation Into Allende’s Death | publisher = ''New York Times'' | accessdate = 2011-01-28 | first=Pascale | last=Bonnefoy | date=27 January 2011}}{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-13096836 | title = Chile to exhume former President Salvador Allende | publisher = ''BBC News'' | accessdate = 2011-05-05 | date=15 April 2011}}{{cite web | url = http://www.lanacion.cl/cuerpo-de-salvador-allende-sera-exhumado-el-23-de-mayo/noticias/2011-05-06/101513.html | title = Cuerpo de Salvador Allende será exhumado el 23 de mayo| publisher = ''La Nación (Chile)'' | accessdate = 2011-05-05}} In May, Allende's remains were exhumed by order of a Chilean court in furtherance of a "criminal investigation into the death of Allende." {{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jul/20/salvador-allende-committed-suicide-autopsy | work=The Guardian | title=Chilean president Salvador Allende committed suicide, autopsy confirms | date=19 July 2011}} On May 31, 2011, before the court-ordered autopsy had been completed, Chile's [[Televisión Nacional de Chile|state television station]] reported that a top-secret military account of Allende's death had been discovered in the home of a former military justice official. The 300-page document was only found when the house was destroyed in the [[2010 Chilean earthquake]]. After reviewing the report, two forensic experts told TVN "that they are inclined to conclude that Allende was assassinated."{{cite news | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/chile-tv-secret-military-report-on-allendes-death-raises-doubts-about-suicide/2011/05/31/AG1rkTFH_story.html | title = Chile TV: Secret military report on Allende’s death raises doubts about suicide |newspaper = [[The Washington Post]]| date=31 May 2011}} Results of the autopsy were officially released in mid-July 2011. The team of Chilean medical experts conducting and reviewing the autopsy results confirmed that Salvador Allende had died from self-inflicted gunshot wounds.{{cite news | url = http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/americas/07/19/chile.allende/index.html | title = Former Chilean President Allende's death confirmed as suicide| publisher = CNN | accessdate = 2011-07-19}} The autopsy results indicated that Allende had died after shooting himself with an [[AK-47]] received as a gift from [[Fidel Castro]]. The shots tore off the top of Allende's head, killing him instantly, because the rifle had been set to automatic fire. ''[[The Guardian]]'', a leading UK newspaper, reported that the "scientific autopsy" had confirmed that "Salvador Allende committed suicide during the 1973 coup that toppled his socialist government." According to ''The Guardian'': {{quote|British ballistics expert David Prayer said Allende died of two shots fired from an assault rifle that was held between his legs and under his chin and was set to fire automatically. The bullets blew out the top of his head and killed him instantly. The forensics team's conclusion was unanimous. Spanish expert Francisco Etxeberria said: "We have absolutely no doubt" that Allende committed suicide.}} ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==References== {{Refbegin}} *{{cite web |url=http://www.oberlin.edu/faculty/svolk/lat102200.htm |title=Out of the Ashes |accessdate=24 July 2009 |author= |last=O'Connor |first=Anne-Marie |authorlink= |date=22 October 2000|work= |publisher=Los Angeles Times |location=Los Angeles, CA |pages= |language= |doi= |quote=Reproduced online on the site of Oberlin College professor Steven S. {{Other uses}} {{cleanup reorganize|date=March 2017}} [[File:Saint Tabitha.jpg|thumb|[[Hagiography]], fresco, of Saint Tabitha in [[Greek Orthodox Church]].]] '''Dorcas''' ({{lang-el|Δορκάς}}, ''Dorkás''; {{lang-arc|טביתא}} ''Ṭabītā'') was a [[disciple (Christianity)|disciple]] who lived in [[Jaffa|Joppa]], referenced in the [[Acts of the Apostles]] ({{bibleverse-nb||Acts|9:36–42}}) in the [[New Testament]].<ref name=Syswerda>{{cite book|last=Syswerda|first=Jean E.|title=Women of the Bible : 52 Bible studies for individuals and groups|year=2002|publisher=Zondervan|location=Grand Rapids, Mich.|isbn=0310244927|page=214}}</ref> Her name in the [[Textus Receptus]] is "Ταβιθά" (Tabitha).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.blueletterbible.org/kjv/act/9/36/p0/t_conc_1027036|title=Acts 9:36 (KJV)|publisher=}}</ref>
In [[October 25]]he [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] celebrates [[Saint]] Tabitha the Widow, raised from the dead by the Apostle Peter<ref>{{cite web | url = https://oca.org/saints/lives/2018/10/25/103058-st-tabitha-the-widow-raised-from-the-dead-by-the-apostle-peter | title = Commemoration of St. Tabitha the Widow | language = en | website = Orthodox Church of America | access-date = Oct 7, 2018 | archive-url = http://archive.is/qNdJk | archive-date = Oct 11, 2018 | deadurl = no}}</ref>.
Acts recounts that when she died, she was mourned by "all the widows...crying and showing (Peter) the robes and other clothing that she had made while she was still with them" (Acts 9:39).<ref name=Syswerda /> The Greek construct used in this passage indicates that the widows were the recipients of her charity,<ref name="Bock">{{cite book|last=Bock|first=Darrell L. |title=Acts (Baker Exegetical Commentary on the New Testament) |year=2007|publisher=Baker Books |isbn=1441200266|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=smkvXcfFBBwC&pg=PA378|page=378}}</ref> but she may also have been a widow herself.<ref name="Gangel">{{cite book|last=Gangel|first=Kenneth O. |title=Holman New Testament Commentary - Acts |year=1998|publisher=B&H Publishing Group |isbn=0805402055 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s_rs-CRacHYC&pg=PA146 |page=146}}</ref> It is likely that she was a woman of some means, given her ability to help the poor.<ref name="Witherington">{{cite book|last=Witherington |first=Ben |title=The Acts of the Apostles: A Socio-rhetorical Commentary |year=1998|publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans |isbn=0802845010 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2P7zSnM9BjMC&pg=PA331 |pages=331–332}}</ref> The disciples present called upon [[Saint Peter|Peter]], who came from nearby [[Lod|Lydda]] to the place where her body was being laid out for burial, and raised her from the dead.<ref name="Witherington"/>
This narrative concerning Tabitha/Dorcas indicates her prominence in the community at Joppa.<ref name="Witherington"/><ref name=Lockyer /> This might also be indicated by the fact that Peter took the trouble to come to her from a neighbouring city, when requested by the community members.
The name ''Dorcas'' is a Greek translation of the Aramaic name ''Tabitha'', meaning "[[gazelle]]".<ref name=Lockyer>{{cite book|last=Lockyer|first=Herbert|title=All the women of the Bible|year=1967|publisher=Zondervan|location=Grand Rapids|isbn=0310281512|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0YrW3bxxGAsC&pg=PA46 |pages=46–48}}</ref> One species of gazelle is now known as the [[Dorcas Gazelle|dorcas gazelle]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Hildyard |first= Anne [ed.] |title=Endangered wildlife and of the world|year=2001|publisher=Marshall Cavendish|location=New York [u.a.]|isbn=0761471944|page=606}}</ref>
==In Christian tradition== [[File:Raising of Tabitha.JPG|thumb|Section of ''Healing of the Cripple and Raising of Tabitha'' by [[Masolino da Panicale]], 1425.]]
Dorcas, along with [[Lydia of Thyatira]] and [[Phoebe (biblical figure)|Phoebe]], is honored with a [[feast day]] on the [[Calendar of saints (Episcopal Church)|liturgical calendar of the Episcopal Church in the United States of America]] on January 27.<ref name="Pfatteicher">{{cite book|last=Pfatteicher|first=Philip H.|title=The new book of festivals and commemorations : a proposed common calendar of saints|year=2008|publisher=Fortress Press|location=Minneapolis|isbn=9780800621285|page=683}}</ref> The Evangelical Lutheran Church also places their [[Calendar of saints (Lutheran)|joint commemoration]] on January 27, immediately after the male missionaries remembered after the feast of St. Paul's Conversion, but the Lutheran Church Missouri Synod (LCMS) commemorates these three faithful women on October 25.<ref name="Pfatteicher"/><ref>{{cite book|last=Kinnaman|first=Scot A.|title=Lutheranism 101|year=2010|publisher=Concordia Publishing House|location=St. Louis|isbn=9780758625052|page=278}}</ref> The Catholic Church commemorates Dorcas (under the Aramaic version of her name, St Tabitha) on October 25,<ref>{{cite book|last=Sheehan|first=Thomas W.|title=Dictionary of Patron Saints' Names |year=2001|publisher=Our Sunday Visitor Publishing |isbn=0879735392|page=268}}</ref> the same date as the Eastern Church.<ref name="Pfatteicher"/> [[Dorcas Society|Dorcas societies]], which provide clothing to the poor, are named after her.<ref name=Lockyer/>
[[File:Dorcas Window Mytholmroyd.jpg|thumb|left|Dorcas Window St. Michael's Parish Church, [[Mytholmroyd]], West Yorkshire]] [[Basil of Caesarea]] refers to Dorcas as an example in his ''Morals'' (rule 74): "That a widow who enjoys sufficiently robust health should spend her life in works of zeal and solicitude, keeping in mind the words of the Apostle and the example of Dorcas."<ref>{{cite book|last=Basil|first=Saint|title=Ascetical Works |year=1999 |publisher=CUA Press |isbn=0813211093 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F4GRmOIddMgC&pg=PA191 |page=191}}</ref> She is also commemorated in poems by [[Robert Herrick (poet)|Robert Herrick]] ("The Widows' Tears: Or, Dirge of Dorcas") and [[George MacDonald]] ("Dorcas").
==In art== Depictions of Dorcas in art can be found as early as the fourth century, and her raising is often included in Medieval and Renaissance illustrations of the life of [[Saint Peter]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Ross|first=Leslie |title=Medieval Art: A Topical Dictionary |year=1996|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |isbn=0313293295 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b-5YPoia7qwC&pg=PA239 |page=239}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Earls|first=Irene |title=Renaissance Art: A Topical Dictionary |year=1987|publisher=ABC-CLIO |isbn=0313293295 |page=226}}</ref>
Dorcas' acts of charity are a common subject of [[stained glass]] church windows. She is represented in a window in the apse of [[Christ Church, Bath]], on the south side of [[St Peter's Church, Caversham]], in [[Church of St Andrew, Cheddar|St. Andrew's Church, Cheddar]], in the sacristy of [[Calvary Episcopal Church (Pittsburgh)]], in [[Llandaff Cathedral]] in [[Cardiff]], in [[St Leonard's Church, Bridgnorth]], in [[Castleton, Derbyshire|Castleton]] Parish Church in Derbyshire, on the north side of St. Nicholas' church in [[Castle Hedingham]] in Essex, in the Ladychapel of St Michael's Church in [[Mytholmroyd]], West Yorkshire, and in an oriel window at the Head Office of the [[Retail Trust]] in north London.
The [[Lady chapel]] of [[St Patrick's Cathedral, Dublin]] has a window of Dorcas with the legend: "Dorcas this woman was full of good works and almsdeeds". Christ Church, [[St. Joseph, Missouri]], depicts her holding a blue cloth in a prominent nave window (1885) on the south side. Grace and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in [[Richmond, Virginia]] has her in a window made in Germany around 1890.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ghtc.org/index.php/about/history-of-grace-and-holy-trinity-church/the-dorcas-window/ |title=Grace & Holy Trinity Church: The Dorcas Window |accessdate=2013-10-27}}</ref>
Dorcas and [[Cornelius the Centurion|Cornelius]] are represented on the stained glass windows above the altar in the Emmanuel Anglican Church in [[Lawson, New South Wales]]. In the church of St. Lawrence, [[Weston under Penyard]], Herefordshire, she is depicted with [[Paul the Apostle|St. Paul]] in a pair of stained glass windows dedicated to the memory of Edward Burdett Hawkshaw, the Rector from 1854-1912, and his wife, Catherine (a photograph nearby in the church shows that his likeness is the face given to St. Paul, while Dorcas has the face of Mrs. Hawkshaw). {{Clear left}}
