{{Infobox animanga character | name = Edward Elric | series = [[Fullmetal Alchemist]] | image = [[File:Edward85as.JPG|200px]] | caption = Art by Hiromu Arakawa | first = ''Fullmetal Alchemist'' manga chapter 1 | creator = [[Hiromu Arakawa]] | voiced by = '''Japanese'''
[[Romi Park]]{{cite episode|title=太陽に挑む者|airdate=October 4, 2003|number=1|credits=Director: Seiji Mizushima|series=Fullmetal Alchemist|network=Tokyo Broadcasting System}}
'''English'''
[[Vic Mignogna]] | oaux1 name = Portrayed by | oaux1 = [[Ryosuke Yamada]], Rai Takahashi (Young) | alias = Fullmetal Alchemist | relatives = [[Alphonse Elric]] (brother)
[[Van Hohenheim]] (father)
[[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Trisha Elric|Trisha Elric]] (mother)
[[Winry Rockbell]] (wife)
Unnamed son
Unnamed daughter |color = #B60000}} {{nihongo|'''Edward Elric'''|エドワード・エルリック|Edowādo Erurikku|lead=yes}}, commonly nicknamed {{nihongo|'''Ed'''|エド|Edo}}, is a [[fictional character]] and the protagonist of the ''[[Fullmetal Alchemist]]'' [[manga]] series created by [[Hiromu Arakawa]]. Edward, titled {{nihongo|"Fullmetal Alchemist"|鋼の錬金術師|Hagane no Renkinjutsushi|lit. "Alchemist of Steel"}}, is the youngest State Alchemist in the history of the fictional country of Amestris. His left leg was divinely severed in a failed attempt to resurrect his dead mother, and then his right arm was taken in exchange for his brother's soul. His missing limbs have been replaced with [[Retrofuturism|sophisticated]] [[Prosthesis|prosthetics]] called {{nihongo|automail|機械鎧(オートメイル)|ōtomeiru}}. He and his younger brother, [[Alphonse Elric|Alphonse]], who lost his entire body and is spiritually bound to a suit of armor, scour the world in search of the [[Philosopher's Stone]] in the hopes of restoring their bodies. Ed has appeared in other media from the series, including [[video games]], [[original video animation]]s (OVAs) and [[light novel]]s. Numerous publications in various media have been written on the subject of Edward's character. Reviewers praised Edward as a balance between the typical clever kid and the stubborn kid persona. Additionally, his comedic moments have been celebrated as some of the best moments in the series. His Japanese and English voice actors, [[Romi Park]] and [[Vic Mignogna]], have both been praised for their performances as Edward Elric and have won several awards for their work. Numerous pieces of merchandise have been released bearing Edward's likeness, including key chains and action figures. ==Creation and conception== Author [[Hiromu Arakawa]] integrated several social problems into the plot, such as the way Edward and Alphonse live as brothers after the death of their mother, Trisha. She also looks at how the brothers help people all over the country to gain an understanding of the meaning of family.{{Cite journal |title=Equivalent Change |journal=[[Newtype USA]] |volume=5 |issue=1 |page=24 | publication-date=January 2006 |publisher=[[A.D. Vision]] }} When describing the character's personality, Arakawa comments that after his father's departure from home and his mother's death, Edward tried to replace the role of the man for the Elric family. As a result, Van Hohenheim's reappearance caused a shocking and terrified reaction in the character.{{cite book | last=Arakawa | first=Hiromu | title=Fullmetal Alchemist Rough Sketch Gallery|trans-title=| year=2006 | publisher=Square Enix|page=29| isbn=978-4-7575-1695-3 }} Arakawa has noted that Edward is one of her favorite characters from the series, although she denied having the same personality as him when one of her assistants mentioned it.{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist Profiles|pages=100–105|year=2006|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=1-4215-0768-4 }} When comparing the two brothers during the time Alphonse obtained the ability to use alchemy without a circle like Edward, Arakawa stated nobody was better at alchemy as the two had different preferences in the same way as other alchemist appearing in the series.{{cite book | last=Arakawa | first=Hiromu | title=鋼の錬金術師 パーフェクトガイドブック 2|trans-title=| year=2005 | publisher=Square Enix|pages=168–172| isbn=978-4-7575-1426-3 }} Although she claims she has not thought of the characters' birthdates, Arakawa noted that she decided Edward's birthdate during the series' serialization. During a chapter in which it was mentioned that Edward was about to be 16, winter was about to begin in Hokkaido, Arakawa's birthplace, so it was decided Edward's birthdate would be in winter.{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 12|year=2007|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|page=184|isbn=978-1-4215-0839-9}} In a common [[slapstick]] gag from the series, Edward is often struck by Winry Rockbell's [[wrench]]. While commenting that Edward has the ability to easily dodge her, Arakawa comments that he gets hit on purpose as a result of his personality.{{cite book | last=Arakawa | first=Hiromu | title=荒川弘イラスト集 FULLMETAL ALCHEMIST 3 | year=2011 | publisher=Square Enix|page=134| isbn=978-4-7575-3220-5}} The director of the first anime series, [[Seiji Mizushima]], says that in the development of the story Edward "evolves and devolves"; Mizushima comments that Edward is continuously overcoming inner struggles in order to determine how to grow up. The appearance of his automail in the anime is used to symbolize the intangibles of his character, making viewers note that Edward lost something important.{{Cite journal |title=Fullmetal Alchemist |journal=[[Newtype USA]] |volume=5 |issue=3 |page=32 | publication-date=March 2006 |publisher=[[A.D. Vision]] }} In a prototype from the series, Edward was an eighteen-year-old teenager travelling alongside his father whose soul sealed in a [[flying squirrel]]. Edward's prototype had an average height, but retained his automail. In order to fit with the readers from the manga magazine ''Monthly Shonen Gangan'', Edward's traits were further modified, leaving his current one. His height was reduced in order to contrast with Alphonse's huge armor.{{cite journal | last=Arakawa | first=Hiromu | journal=TV Bros|title=アニメ開始ごろ|date=December 2003 | publisher=Nyusu|url=http://www3.atwiki.jp/fa/pages/38.html }} In the design of the character, Arakawa is often worried about not making his automail too bulky to avoid balancing it by increasing Edward's muscles, making his appearance unsuitable for his age.{{cite book | last=Arakawa | first=Hiromu | title=Fullmetal Alchemist Rough Sketch Gallery|trans-title=| year=2006 | publisher=Square Enix|page=7| isbn=978-4-7575-1695-3 }} She has also often drawn the character in full body length, but at one point noticed she made it too tall.{{cite book | last=Arakawa | first=Hiromu | title=Fullmetal Alchemist Rough Sketch Gallery|trans-title=| year=2006 | publisher=Square Enix|page=15| isbn=978-4-7575-1695-3 }}{{cite book | last=Arakawa | first=Hiromu | title=Fullmetal Alchemist Rough Sketch Gallery|trans-title=| year=2006 | publisher=Square Enix|page=23| isbn=978-4-7575-1695-3 }} As the manga continued serialization, Arakawa found that she drew Edward half naked several times even more than [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Alex Louis Armstrong|Alex Louis Armstrong]] who tends to show his torso. While stating that this was because she wanted to draw Edward's automail, she commented that it was common for men to walk in underwear at their homes.{{cite book | last=Arakawa | first=Hiromu | title=The Art Of Fullmetal Alchemist| year=2005 | publisher=Viz Media|pages=94–95| isbn=978-1-4215-0158-1 }} In the Japanese version of ''Fullmetal Alchemist''{{'}}s anime adaptations, Edward has been voiced by [[Romi Park]]. In the English version, the role has been played by [[Vic Mignogna]].{{cite episode|title=Those Who Challenge the Sun|airdate=November 6, 2004|credits=Director: Seiji Mizushima|series=Fullmetal Alchemist|network=Cartoon Network}} Mignogna has stated that performing Edward may be his biggest voice acting achievement since fans do not compare him with Park, noting that their voices are not similar and that he did not plan to sound like her.{{cite web|title=Interview with Vic Mignogna|url=http://www.mania.com/being-brief-discussion-vic-mignogna_article_84273.html|author=Jeng, Way|date=April 19, 2005|publisher=Mania Entertainment|accessdate=April 2, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207030519/http://www.mania.com/being-brief-discussion-vic-mignogna_article_84273.html|archivedate=December 7, 2008|df=}} Additionally, in the upcoming live-action of the series, Edward will be portrayed by [[Ryosuke Yamada]].{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2016/04/03-1/dean-fujioka-and-others-join-live-action-fullmetal-alchemist-film|title=Dean Fujioka and Others Join Live-Action "Fullmetal Alchemist" Film |publisher=Crunchyroll|accessdate=April 3, 2016|date=April 3, 2016}} Yamada thinks his short starture might be work as an advantage due to one of Edward's most common characteristics is his low height. Studying Arakawa's manga, Yamada tried imitating Edward's other signature actions such the way he runs. A fan of the series, the actor expressed happiness with the role he was given. Nevertheless, in [[Anime Expo]] 2017 if anything from him looked "weird" which resulted in praise from the audience. During questions, Yamada said that one of the most difficult scenes about his acting is interacting with Alphonse as a result of the latter being CGI. As a result, in the shooting of some scenes the staff had a person in Alphonse's place so that Yamada had a better way to act.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/convention/2017/anime-expo/fullmetal-alchemist-live-action-film-panel-q-a/.118435|title=Fullmetal Alchemist Live-Action Film Panel + Q&A|last=Loveridge|first=Lynzee |publisher=Anime News Network|accessdate=July 5, 2017|date=July 5, 2017}} ==Appearances== ===In ''Fullmetal Alchemist''=== Edward was born in a small town named Resembool in the nation of Amestris, living with his younger brother [[Alphonse Elric|Alphonse]] and their parents [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Trisha Elric|Trisha Elric]] and [[Van Hohenheim]]. After Hohenheim left the family on a journey early in their lives, Edward developed a loathing for their father as he and Alphonse learned to use [[alchemy]] before Trisha died of an illness years later. This two young boys concentrated on studying alchemy in the hopes of bringing their mother back to life, and trained with a skilled alchemist named [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Izumi Curtis|Izumi Curtis]].{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 5|year=2006|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|chapter=Chapter 21|isbn=978-1-4215-0175-8}} When they make the attempt to revive their mother, it failed and the brothers paid a bigger price via the Law of Equivalent Exchange: which states that every outcome requires an equal payment.{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 1|year=2005|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|chapter=Chapter 4|isbn=978-1-59116-920-8}} Edward lost his left leg while meeting the metaphysical being known as {{nihongo4|Truth|真理|Shinri}}, gaining great knowledge as well as the prodigious ability to perform transmutations just by clapping his hands together without the need of a Transmutation Circle.{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 2|year=2005|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|chapter=Chapter 6|page=94|isbn=978-1-59116-923-9}} As Alphonse's entire being was taken by Truth, Edward uses his newly gained knowledge in sacrificing his own right arm to retrieve Alphonse's soul and bind it to a nearby suit of armor. Later meeting Colonel Roy Mustang while being outfitted prosthetic "automail" limbs by the grandmother of his childhood friend, [[Winry Rockbell]], motivated to restore Alphonse,{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 4|year=2005|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|chapter=Chapter 15|page=98|isbn=978-1-59116-929-1}} Edward joins the State Military. He becomes youngest State Alchemist, receiving the title of "Fullmetal Alchemist" shortly thereafter from the military head, [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#King Bradley|King Bradley]]. For the next few years, the Elric Brothers begin an extensive search for the legendary Philosopher's Stone in order to restore their bodies.{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 1|year=2005|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|chapter=Chapter 2|page=82|isbn=978-1-59116-920-8}} Edward is extremely idealistic, and strongly believes in the alchemical concept of "Equivalent Exchange," though he also behaves in a childish manner and can violently lash out when confronted about his short height.{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 1|year=2005|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|chapter=Omake|isbn=978-1-59116-920-8}}{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 4|year=2005|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|chapter=Chapter 14|page=65|isbn=978-1-59116-929-1}} Besides his abilities as an alchemist, Edward is a formidable fighter as a result of his training with Izumi, who had extensively trained both brothers in [[martial arts]].{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 6|year=2006|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|chapter=Chapter 23|isbn=978-1-4215-0319-6|pages=61–63}} During their search for the Stone, from liberating the town of Liore from the cult leader Father Cornello to their tragic meeting with Nina Tucker and her desperate father Shou Tucker, Edward and Alphonse had a near-death experience when attacked by [[Scar (Fullmetal Alchemist)|Scar]], a vengeful Ishbalan targeting State Alchemists for the mass murder of his people during the Ishbal Civil War. This led to the Elrics making a brief return to Resembool with Winry becoming Edward's automail mechanic, the brothers encountering a former State Alchemist named Tim Marcoh who gives them the method of creating a Philosopher's Stone. The brothers, deciding to find another means upon learning human souls are required to create a Philosopher's Stone, get later revelations in the form of immortal beings known as the [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Homunculi|homunculi]].{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 6|year=2006|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|chapter=Chapter 24|page=|isbn=978-1-4215-0319-6}} When Edward and Alphonse discover that the homunculi and the Philosopher's Stone are related, they work together with Mustang and the Xingese prince Lin Yao to find them.{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 11|year=2007|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|chapter=Chapter 45|isbn=978-1-4215-0838-2}} But the Elric brothers meet the homunculus whom the homunculi call "[[Father (Fullmetal Alchemist)|Father]]," who is the true leader of Ametris with Bradley being a human-homunculus. The brothers are forced to keep working with the military as Bradley uses Winry as a hostage.{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 14|year=2007|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|chapter=Chapter 57|isbn=978-1-4215-1379-9}} Forced to comply, the Elrics travel to the northern area of the country in order where they eventually reveal what they known to General [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Olivier Mira Armstrong|Olivier Mira Armstrong]] while dealing with the homunculus Sloth.{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 17|year=2008|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|chapter=Chapter 67|isbn=978-1-4215-2161-9}} Shortly after their arrival, the State Alchemist [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Solf J. Kimblee|Solf J. Kimblee]] bring Winry to the north as a hostage, unknown to Winry, to force Edward's help in hunting Scar.{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 17|year=2008|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|chapter=Chapter 69|isbn=978-1-4215-2161-9}} But the brothers and Scar made their place as they end up using his help so Alphonse can take Winry to safety.{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 18|year=2009|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|chapter=Chapter 73|isbn=978-1-4215-2536-5}} Upon their success, joined by Lin after he willing became a host for Greed, Edward learns the Father's full plan of making human transmutation circle out to create a Philosopher's Stone. Edward later reunites with Alphonse and their father as they and their allies formulate an attack on Central City from all sides.{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 20|year=2009|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|chapter=Chapter 83|isbn=978-1-4215-3034-5}} The group make their way into the underground complex while dispatching many of the homunculi, but the Elric Brothers, Izumi, Honenhiem, and Mustang are captured by Father who uses them to absorb the souls of Amestrians to absorb the being beyond the Gate of Truth.{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 25|chapter=Chapter 102|year=2011|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-4215-3924-9}} But Honenheim and Scar act out their backup plans to return the recently stolen souls to their bodies and enable every alchemist to fighting the severely weakened Father. Joining the fray after defeating Pride, Edward loses his automail while battling Father. Alphonse transmutes his soul in order to restore Edward's original flesh-and-blood arm.{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 27|year=2011|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|chapter=Chapter 107|isbn=978-1-4215-3984-3}} After defeating Father, Edward manages to bring Alphonse back by sacrificing his own ability to use alchemy. The brothers return to their hometown to live normal lives, but are motivated by the memories of Nina and others they failed to save to learn new methods of alchemy to prevent such tragedies from being repeated. Two years later, Edward decides to head westward for their research with Winry accompanying him as they progressively developed a romantic relationship over the course of their adventure and eventually confessed their feelings to each other.{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 15|year=2007|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|chapter=Chapter 58|isbn=978-1-4215-1380-5}} In the epilogue, Edward and Winry are revealed to have married and have a son and daughter together.{{cite book|last=Arakawa|first=Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 27|year=2011|publisher=[[Viz Media]]|chapter=Chapter 108|isbn=978-1-4215-3984-3}} ===In the first anime=== Although following the series storyline to an extent, the first anime's storyline diverts with Edward learning the secret to destroying a homunculus during his encounter with Greed, whom he kills in an effort to save Alphonse.{{cite episode|title=Theory of Avarice|airdate=November 5, 2005|number=34|credits=Director: Seiji Mizushima|series=Fullmetal Alchemist|serieslink=Fullmetal Alchemist|network=Cartoon Network}} When he learns of Scar's creation of a Philosopher's Stone within Alphonse, Edward saves the people of Lior from being sacrificed for its creation.{{cite episode|title=His Name Is Unknown|airdate=January 14, 2006|number=42|credits=Director: Seiji Mizushima|series=Fullmetal Alchemist|serieslink=Fullmetal Alchemist|network=Cartoon Network}} During his battle against the homunculi, Edward is killed by [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Envy|Envy]], but Alphonse trades himself for his brothers' revival. In doing so, however, Alphonse's armor with the philosopher's stone within it is used up and he disappears. After being revived, Edward sacrifices his own life to bring back his brother in exchange. As a result, Edward finds himself on the other side of the Gate, a [[Parallel universe (fiction)|parallel world]] which greatly resembles the real world during [[World War II]], while Alphonse recovers his original body. Determined to return to Alphonse, Edward becomes involved in rocketry research in [[Germany]], with the intention of using that technology to return to his home world.{{cite episode|title=Laws and Promises|airdate=March 18, 2006|number=51|credits=Director: Seiji Mizushima|series=Fullmetal Alchemist|serieslink=Fullmetal Alchemist|network=Cartoon Network}} In the feature film, ''[[Fullmetal Alchemist the Movie: Conqueror of Shamballa]]'', set two years after the end of the anime, Edward has been living in Germany and looks for a way to return to his world. At the film's end, he decides to stay in the parallel world along with Alphonse so that they may try to protect both worlds.{{cite video|people=Mizushima, Seiji (Director) |date=July 23, 2005 |url=http://www.sonymusic.co.jp/Animation/hagaren/hagaren-movie/index.html |title=Fullmetal Alchemist the Movie: Conqueror of Shambala |medium=Motion picture |location=Japan |publisher=Bones |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070318042714/http://www.sonymusic.co.jp/Animation/hagaren/hagaren-movie/index.html |archivedate=March 18, 2007 |df= }} ===In other media=== Edward also appears in almost all the [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist episodes#OVAs|''Fullmetal Alchemist'' original video animations]] (OVAs). In the first OVA he appears as a [[super deformed]] version of himself at the movie's wrap-up party; in the second, he appears shortly as an old man living in modern-day Tokyo; and in the third OVA, he plays a part in the battle against the first anime's [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Homunculi|homunculi]].{{cite video |date = 2009 |title = Fullmetal Alchemist: Premium OVA Collection|type=[[DVD]]|publisher = Funimation}} As the series' titular character, Edward is playable in all [[Fullmetal Alchemist#Video games|''Fullmetal Alchemist'' video games]]. The three games for the [[PlayStation 2]] – ''[[Fullmetal Alchemist and the Broken Angel]]'', ''[[Fullmetal Alchemist 2: Curse of the Crimson Elixir|Curse of the Crimson Elixir]]'' and ''[[Fullmetal Alchemist 3: Kami o Tsugu Shōjo|Kami o Tsugu Shōjo]]'' – feature exclusive stories in which the Elrics keep searching for the Philosopher's Stone.{{cite web|url=http://na.square-enix.com/games/FMA/|publisher=[[Square Enix]]|title=Fullmetal Alchemist and the Broken Angel official website|accessdate=March 23, 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://na.square-enix.com/games/FMA2/|publisher=[[Square Enix]]|title=Fullmetal Alchemist 2: Curse of the Crimson Elixir official website|accessdate=March 23, 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://www.square-enix.co.jp/hagaren3/|publisher=[[Square Enix]]|title=Fullmetal Alchemist 3: Kami o Tsugu Shōjo official website|accessdate=March 23, 2008}} In the Nintendo DS game, ''Fullmetal Alchemist Dual Sympathy'', he and Alphonse replay the first anime series. He is also featured in the ''Fullmetal Alchemist Trading Card Game''.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000ARTBV2/|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|title=Fullmetal Alchemist Booster Box|accessdate=March 31, 2008}} There are two [[Image album|character CD]]s featuring tracks based on Edward's character. The first is named {{nihongo|''Hagaren Song File – Edward Elric''|Hagaren Song File – エドワード・エルリック}} and the second ''Theme of Edward Elric''. Both albums were performed by Ed's Japanese voice actress, [[Romi Park]].{{cite web | title=Hagaren song file – Edward Elric – Single Maxi Soundtrack | url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B000BV7XYY/| publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|language=Japanese|accessdate=August 1, 2009}}{{cite web | title=Theme of Edward Elric by The Alchemists Maxi| url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B002EBDMAI/| publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|language=Japanese|accessdate=October 12, 2009}} He also appears in each [[light novel]] written by Makoto Inoue which continue Ed and Al's search for the Philosopher's Stone and at the same time feature different stories from the ones appearing the manga and the anime.{{cite book|author=Inoue, Makoto|title=Fullmetal Alchemist: Under the Faraway Sky|year=2007|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-4215-1397-3}}{{cite book|author=Inoue, Makoto|title=Fullmetal Alchemist: The Ties That Bind|year=2007|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-4215-1431-4}} ==Reception== [[File:Vic Mignogna by Gage Skidmore 2.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Vic Mignogna]], who voices the character in the English dub, has received praise.]] Edward's character is well received by manga readers; in each of the popularity polls made by ''[[Gangan Comics#Monthly Shōnen Gangan|Monthly Shōnen Gangan]]'' he has ranked first.{{cite book | last=Arakawa | first=Hiromu | title=Fullmetal Alchemist Profiles| year=2006 | publisher=Viz Media |page=5| isbn=1-4215-0768-4 }}{{cite book | last=Arakawa | first=Hiromu | title=鋼の錬金術師 キャラクターガイド|trans-title=Fullmetal Alchemist Character Guide| year=2009 | publisher=Square Enix |page=3| isbn=978-4-7575-2574-0 }} Edward also won the Twenty-sixth Annual ''[[Animage]]'' Readers' Poll, [[Anime Grand Prix]], in the "Favorite Male Character"; Romi Park, who voices Edward in Japanese, won in the "Favorite Seiyu" category.{{cite web|title=Animage Awards|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2004-05-12/animage-awards|publisher=Anime News Network|date= May 12, 2004|accessdate=April 8, 2008}} Edward maintained a high place in the next year's poll in the same category.{{cite web|url=http://animage.jp/old/gp/gp_2005.html |script-title=ja:第26回アニメグランプリ　2005年6月号 |publisher=[[Animage]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=April 11, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090627174422/http://animage.jp/old/gp/gp_2005.html |archivedate=June 27, 2009 |df= }} In the July 2009 issue of ''[[Newtype]]'', Edward ranked at the top of the survey Male Character Rankings.{{cite journal |journal=[[Newtype]], Issue 8|date=July 2009|publisher=[[Kadokawa Shoten]]|title=NT Research}} In the August 2009 issue his rank changed to fourth.{{cite journal |journal=[[Newtype]], Issue 9|date=August 2009|publisher=[[Kadokawa Shoten]]|title=NT Research}} In a ''Newtype'' poll from March 2010, Edward was voted as the fourth most popular male anime character from the 2000s.{{cite journal |journal=[[Newtype]], Issue 4|date=March 2010|publisher=[[Kadokawa Shoten]]|title=NT Research}} In the Anime Awards 2006 from [[About.com]], Edward won in the category "Best Lead Character – Male".{{cite web|url=http://anime.about.com/od/toppicks/ig/2006Awards/leadmale.htm|author=Luther, Katherine|title=Best Lead Character – Male|publisher=About.com|accessdate=January 17, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202225617/http://anime.about.com/od/toppicks/ig/2006Awards/leadmale.htm|archivedate=December 2, 2008|df=}} He was also seventh in [[IGN]]'s 2009 Top 25 Anime Characters of All Time with writer Chris Mackenzie saying, "[Edward] and his kid brother Al make one of the best action-comedy teams in recent memory".{{cite web|url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/103/1036651p4.html|title=Top 25 Anime Characters of All Time|date=October 20, 2009|author=Mackenzie, Chris |publisher=[[IGN]]|accessdate=October 21, 2009}} In 2014, IGN ranked him as the eighth greatest anime character of all time, saying that "In Edward we had a character who was truly multidimensional. He could be comedic and pull off wild takes and sight gags. He could be placed in the most tragic circumstances and portray the deepest kind of sadness. He could be a complete badass, but he could also be the nicest guy on the planet."{{cite web | url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/02/04/top-25-greatest-anime-characters?page=4 | title=Top 25 Greatest Anime Characters | author=Isler, Ramsey | date=February 4, 2014 | publisher=IGN | accessdate=March 13, 2014}} Several pieces of merchandise have been released in Edward's likeness, including plush toys,{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000HEKVF8/|title=Full Metal Alchemist Edward Elric Plush GE-6934 |publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=March 23, 2008}} action figures,{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0006YXVSI/|title=Fullmetal Alchemist Edward Elric Play Arts Action Figure|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=March 23, 2008}} and key-chains.{{cite web|url=http://japanimation.com/index.php?url=Inventory_GeneralsDetail.jsp?arg=dt%253DInventory_Generals%2526mid%253D9855682130%2526usr%253D%2526cid%253D%2526id%253D7374%2526typ%253Dcl%2526aff%253D|publisher=Japanimation|title=Keychain (PVC): FullMetal Alchemist: Edward#2 (Stand)|accessdate=March 23, 2008}} [[Vic Mignogna]], who performs the voice of Edward in the English [[Dubbing (filmmaking)|dub]], was the winner in [[American Anime Awards]] in the category "Best Actor" for voicing Edward.{{cite web|url= http://www.icv2.com/articles/news/10138.html |title= American Anime Award Winners|publisher= ICv2 |date= February 26, 2007 |accessdate= February 13, 2008}} In a poll by Anime News Network, he was voted as the 5th best "guy".{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/the-list/2017-05-20/.116359|title=The List 6 Villains That Saved the Day |date=May 20, 2017 |accessdate=May 21, 2017 |publisher=[[Anime News Network]]}} Several publications for manga, anime, and other pop culture media have provided both praise and criticism on Edward's character. IGN writer Hilary Goldstein praises Edward as the perfect balance between the typical clever kid and the stubborn kid persona, explaining that this allows the character to "float between comical moments and underlying drama without seeming false."{{cite web|url=http://comics.ign.com/articles/598/598355p1.html|title=Fullmetal Alchemist Vol. 1 Review|author=Goldstein, Hilary|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=March 5, 2005|accessdate=March 23, 2008}} Additionally, Melissa Harper from [[Anime News Network]] praises Edward's facial expressions as some of the most humorous highlights of the series, including also the moments in which he reacts quite violently to comments about his small stature. They also praise him for not being a stereotypical ''[[Shōnen manga|shōnen]]'' character as it is noted that he has "very real skills, relationships, and personality".{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/fullmetal-alchemist-gn-1-3|author=Harper, Melissa|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|title=Fullmetal Alchemist gn 1–3|date=November 11, 2006|accessdate=March 23, 2008}} Samuel Arbogast from T.H.E.M. Anime Reviews also comments that the interaction between the Elric brothers as they travel is interesting, and praises their humor scenes as they help to balance the dark parts of the series.{{cite web|url=http://www.themanime.org/viewreview.php?id=719|title=T.H.E.M. Anime Reviews: FullMetal Alchemist Review|publisher=T.H.E.M. Anime Reviews|author= Arbogast, Samuel|accessdate=March 23, 2008}} Similarly, Mania Entertainment's Jarred Pine liked the dynamic between the Elrics brothers as while Edward is often faced with following "dark paths" in the same way as villains with the series, he is always supported by Alphonse who makes sure he is okay.{{cite web|url=http://www.mania.com/fullmetal-alchemist-vol-02_article_82156.html|title=Fullmetal Alchemist Vol. #02|publisher=Mania Entertainment|date=August 2, 2005|author=Jarred Pine|accessdate=September 11, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120111234114/http://www.mania.com/fullmetal-alchemist-vol-02_article_82156.html|archivedate=January 11, 2012|df=}} Judge Joel Pearce from [[DVD Verdict]] commented on Edward's journey, considering it very complex morally because he is trying to do good within a morally questionable organization.{{cite web|url=http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/fullmetalalchemistvol3.php|date=July 28, 2005|author=Pearce, Judge Joel|title=Fullmetal Alchemist: Equivalent Exchange (Volume 3)|publisher=[[DVD Verdict]]|accessdate=January 12, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090102204210/http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/fullmetalalchemistvol3.php|archivedate=January 2, 2009|df=}} Lydia Hojnacki listed Ed as one of the reasons she likes ''Fullmetal Alchemist'', noting the progression of the character's personality throughout the series, from simple maturity to a deeper sensitivity.{{Cite web|title=Three Reasons Why I Love Fullmetal Alchemist |author=Hojnacki, Lydia |url=http://www.popcultureshock.com/manga/index.php/manga-recon/three-reasons-why-i-love-full-metal-alchemist/ |work=Pop Culture Shock |date=December 31, 2008 |accessdate=July 15, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090406004513/http://www.popcultureshock.com/manga/index.php/manga-recon/three-reasons-why-i-love-full-metal-alchemist/ |archivedate=April 6, 2009 |df= }} The character was noted to go through a notable development in the manga after meeting his father by Holly Ellingwood from Active Anime as it made him decide to see the investigate from the human he and Alphonse created as children which led him to find a clue about how to recover his brother's body.{{Cite web |title=Fullmetal Alchemist Vol. 11 |author=Ellingwood, Holly |url=http://activeanime.com/html/2007/03/03/fullmetal-alchemist-vol-11/ |work=Active Anime |date=March 3, 2007 |accessdate=December 4, 2011 }} On the other hand, Maria Lin from Animefringe criticized Edward's development in the first animated adaptation of ''Fullmetal Alchemist'', as in the series' finale he once again attempted to resurrect a human.{{cite web |url=http://www.animefringe.com/magazine/2005/04/special/04.php|title=Animefringe.com: Anime Debunked: Fullmetal Hype|publisher=Animefringe|date=April 2005|author=Lin, Maria|accessdate=April 10, 2008}} When reviewing the video game ''[[Fullmetal Alchemist and the Broken Angel]]'', RPGFan's Neal Chandran enjoyed the dynamic between the main characters both in fights as well as dialogues.{{cite web |url=http://www.rpgfan.com/reviews/Fullmetal_Alchemist/index.html|title=Fullmetal Alchemist and the Broken Angel|accessdate=2016-11-12 |author=Chandran, Neal|date=July 6, 2010 |publisher=RPG Fan}} In ''(Fullmetal) alchemy: the monstrosity of reading words and pictures in shonen manga'', Lesley-Anne Gallacher addressed how the backstory of Edward and Alphonse's failed attempt to revive their mother relate to Shou Tucker's plan to combine his daughter Nina and dog into a monster named chimera. During the discovery of this, Edward and Alphonse are given their own contrast in terms of characterization with the former showing early shock due to understanding what happened to Nina. Nevertheless, Alphonse later reacts violently too once understanding the identity of the chimera. As a result, the writer believes the story "weaken the boundaries between different realms of representation is to compromise the integrity of them all".{{cite journal |last= Gallacher|first= Lesley-Anne |year= 2011|title=(Fullmetal) alchemy: the monstrosity of reading words and pictures in shonen manga |work=Sage Pub |publisher= |publication-place= |page= |url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/1474474010397639 |accessdate=July 8, 2018 |isbn= |issn= |oclc= }} Julie Sadlier from [[York University]] notes how complex is Edward's case of disability despite being a [[supercrip]] through his automail; despite acquiring these metallic limbs, Edward still feels at traumatized from his past and searches for a way to recover his lost arm and leg. Sadlier further commented on Edward's past, comparing it with Ishvalian's civil war who also suffered a tragic loss, most notably the antagonistic Scar who also lost his arm. Other foils noticed by the writer are Lan Fan who amputated herself to aid Ling Yao while noting that through his automail, Arakawa managed to link Edward with Alphonse and Winry.{{cite journal |last= Sadlier|first=Julie|year=2013 |title=Embodiment, Disability and Social Violence in Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood|work= |publisher=York University|publication-place= |page= |url=https://surface.syr.edu/bts_conf/2013/Presentations/4/ |accessdate=July 14, 2018 |isbn= |issn= |oclc= }} Tien-yi Chao from Intellect commented on Edward's characterization in the film ''Conqueror of Shamballa''. Across the movie, Edward meets parallel version of people he met including Maes Hughes (a Nazi soldier with the same name) and King Bradley, (a Jewish director film director named [[Fritz Lang]]), who behave differently from their Amestris counterparts. Chao addresses that through this exchanges the film also parallels itself from Arakawa's original work that takes a different path in terms of story. Nevertheless, Edward also faces the idea of going back to Amestris and comes in terms with Earth during the climax: in confrontation to Exckhart from the [[Thule Society]], Edward notes that both worlds share similar issues, most notably wars which might become easier to occur if the worlds are connected. As a result, Edward and Alphonse decide to live in the real world in order to protect it from nuclear weapons mentioned across the story.{{cite journal |last= Chao|first=Tien-yi|year=2013 |title=Transmutation of worlds: Adaptation and transformation in Fullmetal Alchemist the Movie: Conqueror of Shamballa|work= |publisher=Intellect |publication-place= |page= |url=https://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/intellect/stic/2013/00000004/00000001/art00012 |accessdate=July 14, 2018 |isbn= |issn= |oclc= }} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Fullmetal Alchemist}} {{good article}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Elric, Edward}} [[Category:Anime and manga martial artists]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 2001]] [[Category:Fictional alchemists]] [[Category:Fictional amputees]] [[Category:Fictional atheists and agnostics]] [[Category:Fictional characters with elemental transmutation abilities]] [[Category:Fictional child soldiers]] [[Category:Fictional cyborgs]] [[Category:Fictional majors]] [[Category:Fullmetal Alchemist characters]] [[Category:Male characters in anime and manga]] [[Category:Orphan characters in anime and manga]] [[Category:Square Enix protagonists]] [[Category:Teenage characters in anime and manga]] [[Category:Teenage characters in television]]

Electronic skin refers to [[flexible electronics|flexible]], [[stretchable electronics|stretchable]] and [[Self-healing material|self-healing]] electronics that are able to mimic functionalities of human or animal skin.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Benight|first=Stephanie J.|last2=Wang|first2=Chao|last3=Tok|first3=Jeffrey B.H.|last4=Bao|first4=Zhenan|title=Stretchable and self-healing polymers and devices for electronic skin|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S007967001300097X|journal=Progress in Polymer Science|volume=38|issue=12|pages=1961–1977|doi=10.1016/j.progpolymsci.2013.08.001}}</ref> The broad class of materials often contain sensing abilities that are intended to reproduce the capabilities of human skin to respond to environmental factors such as changes in heat and pressure.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Chou|first=Ho-Hsiu|last2=Nguyen|first2=Amanda|last3=Chortos|first3=Alex|last4=To|first4=John W. F.|last5=Lu|first5=Chien|last6=Mei|first6=Jianguo|last7=Kurosawa|first7=Tadanori|last8=Bae|first8=Won-Gyu|last9=Tok|first9=Jeffrey B.-H.|date=2015-08-24|title=A chameleon-inspired stretchable electronic skin with interactive colour changing controlled by tactile sensing|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms9011|journal=Nature Communications|language=En|volume=6|pages=8011|doi=10.1038/ncomms9011}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Hou|first=Chengyi|last2=Huang|first2=Tao|last3=Wang|first3=Hongzhi|last4=Yu|first4=Hao|last5=Zhang|first5=Qinghong|last6=Li|first6=Yaogang|date=2013-11-05|title=A strong and stretchable self-healing film with self-activated pressure sensitivity for potential artificial skin applications|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/srep03138|journal=Scientific Reports|language=En|volume=3|issue=1|doi=10.1038/srep03138|issn=2045-2322}}</ref>
Advances in electronic skin research focuses on designing materials that are stretchy, robust, and flexible. Research in the individual fields of flexible electronics and [[tactile sensor|tactile sensing]] has progressed greatly; however, electronic skin design attempts to bring together advances in many areas of materials research without sacrificing individual benefits from each field.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Hammock|first=Mallory L.|last2=Chortos|first2=Alex|last3=Tee|first3=Benjamin C.-K.|last4=Tok|first4=Jeffrey B.-H.|last5=Bao|first5=Zhenan|date=2013-11-01|title=25th Anniversary Article: The Evolution of Electronic Skin (E-Skin): A Brief History, Design Considerations, and Recent Progress|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/adma.201302240/abstract|journal=Advanced Materials|language=en|volume=25|issue=42|pages=5997–6038|doi=10.1002/adma.201302240|issn=1521-4095}}</ref> The successful combination of flexible and stretchable mechanical properties with sensors and the ability to self-heal would open the door to many possible applications including [[soft robotics]], prosthetics, artificial intelligence and health monitoring.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bauer|first=Siegfried|last2=Bauer-Gogonea|first2=Simona|last3=Graz|first3=Ingrid|last4=Kaltenbrunner|first4=Martin|last5=Keplinger|first5=Christoph|last6=Schwödiauer|first6=Reinhard|date=2014-01-01|title=25th Anniversary Article: A Soft Future: From Robots and Sensor Skin to Energy Harvesters|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/adma.201303349/abstract|journal=Advanced Materials|language=en|volume=26|issue=1|pages=149–162|doi=10.1002/adma.201303349|issn=1521-4095}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Tee|first=Benjamin C-K.|last2=Wang|first2=Chao|last3=Allen|first3=Ranulfo|last4=Bao|first4=Zhenan|date=December 2012|title=An electrically and mechanically self-healing composite with pressure- and flexion-sensitive properties for electronic skin applications|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/nnano.2012.192|journal=Nature Nanotechnology|language=En|volume=7|issue=12|pages=825–832|doi=10.1038/nnano.2012.192|issn=1748-3395}}</ref>
Recent advances in the field of electronic skin have focused on incorporating green materials ideals and environmental awareness into the design process. As one of the main challenges facing electronic skin development is the ability of the material to withstand mechanical strain and maintain sensing ability or electronic properties, recyclability and self-healing properties are especially critical in the future design of new electronic skins.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Zou|first=Zhanan|last2=Zhu|first2=Chengpu|last3=Li|first3=Yan|last4=Lei|first4=Xingfeng|last5=Zhang|first5=Wei|last6=Xiao|first6=Jianliang|date=2018-02-01|title=Rehealable, fully recyclable, and malleable electronic skin enabled by dynamic covalent thermoset nanocomposite|url=http://advances.sciencemag.org/content/4/2/eaaq0508|journal=Science Advances|language=en|volume=4|issue=2|pages=eaaq0508|doi=10.1126/sciadv.aaq0508|issn=2375-2548}}</ref>
==Rehealable electronic skin== Self-healing abilities of electronic skin are critical to potential applications of electronic skin in fields such as soft robotics.<ref name=":4" /> Proper design of self-healing electronic skin requires not only healing of the base substrate but also the reestablishment of any sensing functions such as tactile sensing or electrical conductivity.<ref name=":4" /> Ideally, the self-healing process of electronic skin does not rely upon outside stimulation such as increased temperature, pressure, or solvation.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /> Self-healing, or rehealable, electronic skin is often achieved through a polymer-based material or a hybrid material.
===Polymer-based materials=== In 2018, Zou ''et al.'' published work on electronic skin that is able to reform covalent bonds when damaged.<ref name=":5" /> The group looked at a polyimine-based crosslinked network, synthesized as seen in Figure 1. The e-skin is considered rehealable because of “reversible bond exchange,” meaning that the bonds holding the network together are able to break and reform under certain conditions such as solvation and heating. The rehealable and reusable aspect of such a thermoset material is unique because many thermoset materials irreversibly form crosslinked networks through covalent bonds.<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|title=Principles of Polymerization|last=Odian|first=George|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|year=2004|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> In the polymer network the bonds formed during the healing process are indistinguishable from the original polymer network. [[File:Polymerization scheme for formation of polyimine-based self-healing e-skin.svg|center|thumb|450x450px|Figure 1. Polymerization scheme for formation of polyimine-based self-healing electronic skin. ]]
Dynamic non-covalent crosslinking has also been shown to form a polymer network that is rehealable. In 2016, Oh ''et al.'' looked specifically at semiconducting polymers for organic transistors.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Oh|first=Jin Young|last2=Rondeau-Gagné|first2=Simon|last3=Chiu|first3=Yu-Cheng|last4=Chortos|first4=Alex|last5=Lissel|first5=Franziska|last6=Wang|first6=Ging-Ji Nathan|last7=Schroeder|first7=Bob C.|last8=Kurosawa|first8=Tadanori|last9=Lopez|first9=Jeffrey|date=November 2016|title=Intrinsically stretchable and healable semiconducting polymer for organic transistors|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/nature20102|journal=Nature|language=En|volume=539|issue=7629|pages=411–415|doi=10.1038/nature20102|issn=1476-4687}}</ref> They found that incorporating 2,6-pyridine dicarboxamide (PDCA) into the polymer backbone could impart self-healing abilities based on the network of hydrogen bonds formed between groups. With incorporation of PDCA in the polymer backbone, the materials was able to withstand up to 100% strain without showing signs of microscale cracking. In this example, the hydrogen bonds are available for energy dissipation as the strain increases.
===Hybrid materials=== Polymer networks are able to facilitate dynamic healing processes through hydrogen bonds or dynamic covalent chemistry.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":7" /> However, the incorporation of inorganic particles can greatly expand the functionality of polymer-based materials for electronic skin applications. The incorporation of micro-structured nickel particles into a polymer network (Figure 2) has been shown to maintain self-healing properties based on the reformation of hydrogen bonding networks around the inorganic particles.<ref name=":4" /> The material is able to regain its conductivity within 15 seconds of breakage, and the mechanical properties are regained after 10 minutes at room temperature without added stimulus. This material relies on hydrogen bonds formed between urea groups when they align. The hydrogen atoms of urea functional groups are ideally situated to form a hydrogen-bonding network because they are near an electron-withdrawing carbonyl group.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Amendola|first=Valeria|last2=Fabbrizzi|first2=Luigi|last3=Mosca|first3=Lorenzo|date=2010-09-17|title=Anion recognition by hydrogen bonding: urea-based receptors|url=http://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=b822552b|journal=Chemical Society Reviews|language=en|volume=39|issue=10|doi=10.1039/b822552b|issn=1460-4744}}</ref> This polymer network with embedded nickel particles demonstrates the possibility of using polymers as supramolecular hosts to develop self-healing conductive composites.<ref name=":4" /> [[File:Self-healing material based on hydrogen bonding and interactions with micro-structured nickel particles.svg|center|thumb|647x647px|Figure 2. Self-healing material based on hydrogen bonding and interactions with micro-structured nickel particles.]]
Flexible and porous graphene foams that are interconnected in a 3D manner have also been shown to have self-healing properties.<ref name=":2" /> Thin film with poly(N,N-dimethylacrylamde)-poly(vinyl alcohol) (PDMAA) and reduced graphene oxide have shown high electrical conductivity and self-healing properties. The healing abilities of the hybrid composite are suspected to be due to the hydrogen bonds between the PDMAA chains, and the healing process is able to restore initial length and recover conductive properties.<ref name=":2" />
== Recyclable electronic skin == Zou ''et al''. presents an interesting advance in the field of electronic skin that can be used in robotics, prosthetics, and many other applications in the form of a fully recyclable electronic skin material.<ref name=":5" /> The e-skin developed by the group consists of a network of covalently bound polymers that are thermoset, meaning cured at a specific temperature. However, the material is also recyclable and reusable. Because the polymer network is thermoset, it is chemically and thermally stable.<ref name=":6" /> However, at room temperature, the polyimine material, with or without silver nanoparticles, can be dissolved on the timescale of a few hours. The recycling process allows devices, which are damaged beyond self-healing capabilities, to be dissolved and formed into new devices (Figure 3).<ref name=":5" /> This advance opens the door for lower cost production and greener approaches to e-skin development. [[File:Recycling process for conductive polyimine-based e-skin.svg|center|thumb|500x500px|Figure 3. Recycling process for conductive polyimine-based e-skin. ]]
== Flexible and stretchy electronic skin == The ability of electronic skin to withstand mechanical deformation including stretching and flexing without losing functionality is crucial for its applications as prosthetics, artificial intelligence, soft robotics, health monitoring, biocompatibility, and communication devices.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Savagatrup|first=Suchol|last2=Zhao|first2=Xikang|last3=Chan|first3=Esther|last4=Mei|first4=Jianguo|last5=Lipomi|first5=Darren J.|date=2016-10-01|title=Effect of Broken Conjugation on the Stretchability of Semiconducting Polymers|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/marc.201600377/abstract|journal=Macromolecular Rapid Communications|language=en|volume=37|issue=19|pages=1623–1628|doi=10.1002/marc.201600377|issn=1521-3927}}</ref> Flexible electronics are often designed by depositing electronic materials on flexible polymer substrates, thereby relying on an organic substrate to impart favorable mechanical properties.<ref name=":0" /> Stretchable e-skin materials have been approached from two directions. Hybrid materials can rely on an organic network for stretchiness while embedding inorganic particles or sensors, which are not inherently stretchable. Other research has focused on developing stretchable materials that also have favorable electronic or sensing capabilities.<ref name=":0" />
Zou ''et al.'' studied the inclusion of linkers that are described as “serpentine” in their polyimine matrix.<ref name=":5" /> These linkers make the e-skin sensors able to flex with movement and distortion. The incorporation of alkyl spacers in polymer-based materials has also been shown to increase flexibility without decreasing charge transfer mobility.<ref name=":7" /> Oh ''et al.'' developed a stretchable and flexible material based on 3,6-di(thiophen-2-yl)-2,5-dihydropyrrolo[3,4-''c'']pyrrole-1,4-dione (DPP) and non-conjugated 2,6-pyridine dicarboxamide (PDCA) as a source of hydrogen bonds (Figure 4).<ref name=":7" /> [[File:A stretchable and self-healing seminconducting polymer-based material.svg|center|thumb|647x647px|Figure 4. A stretchable and self-healing semiconducting polymer-based material.]]
Graphene has also been show to be a suitable material for electronic skin applications as well due to its stiffness and tensile strength.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Núñez|first=Carlos García|last2=Navaraj|first2=William Taube|last3=Polat|first3=Emre O.|last4=Dahiya|first4=Ravinder|date=2017-05-01|title=Energy-Autonomous, Flexible, and Transparent Tactile Skin|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/adfm.201606287/abstract|journal=Advanced Functional Materials|language=en|volume=27|issue=18|pages=n/a–n/a|doi=10.1002/adfm.201606287|issn=1616-3028}}</ref> Graphene is an appealing material because its synthesis to flexible substrates is scalable and cost-efficient.<ref name=":8" />
== Conductive electronic skin == The development of conductive electronic skin is of interest for many electrical applications.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":4" /><ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Segev-Bar|first=Meital|last2=Landman|first2=Avigail|last3=Nir-Shapira|first3=Maayan|last4=Shuster|first4=Gregory|last5=Haick|first5=Hossam|date=2013-06-26|title=Tunable Touch Sensor and Combined Sensing Platform: Toward Nanoparticle-based Electronic Skin|url=https://doi.org/10.1021/am400757q|journal=ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces|volume=5|issue=12|pages=5531–5541|doi=10.1021/am400757q|issn=1944-8244}}</ref> Research into conductive electronic skin has taken two routes: conductive self-healing polymers or embedding conductive inorganic materials in non-conductive polymer networks.<ref name=":0" />
The self-healing conductive composite synthesized by Tee ''et al''. (Figure 2)<ref name=":4" /> investigated the incorporation of micro-structured nickel particles into a polymer host. The nickel particles adhere to the network though favorable interactions between the native oxide layer on the surface of the particles and the hydrogen-bonding polymer.<ref name=":4" />
Nanoparticles have also been studied for their ability to impart conductivity on electronic skin materials.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":9" /> Zou ''et al.'' embedded silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) into a polymer matrix, making the e-skin conductive. The healing process for this material is noteworthy because it not only restores the mechanical properties of the polymer network, but also restores the conductive properties when silver nanoparticles have been embedded in the polymer network.<ref name=":5" />
== Sensing ability of electronic skin == Some of the challenges that face electronic skin sensing abilities include the fragility of sensors, the recovery time of sensors, repeatability, overcoming mechanical strain, and long-term stability.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Park|first=Minhoon|last2=Park|first2=Yong Ju|last3=Chen|first3=Xiang|last4=Park|first4=Yon-Kyu|last5=Kim|first5=Min-Seok|last6=Ahn|first6=Jong-Hyun|date=2016-04-01|title=MoS2-Based Tactile Sensor for Electronic Skin Applications|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/adma.201505124/abstract|journal=Advanced Materials|language=en|volume=28|issue=13|pages=2556–2562|doi=10.1002/adma.201505124|issn=1521-4095}}</ref>
===Tactile sensors=== Applied pressure can be measured by monitoring changes in resistance or capacitance.<ref name=":8" /> Coplanar interdigitated electrodes embedded on single-layer graphene have been shown to provide pressure sensitivity for applied pressure as low as 0.11 kPa through measuring changes in capacitance.<ref name=":8" /> Piezoresistive sensors have also shown high levels of sensitivity.<ref name=":10" />
Ultrathin molybdenum disulfide sensing arrays integrated with graphene have demonstrated promising mechanical properties capable of pressure sensing.<ref name=":10" /> Modifications of organic field effect transistors (OFETs) have shown promise in electronic ski applications.<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Mannsfeld|first=Stefan C. B.|last2=Tee|first2=Benjamin C-K.|last3=Stoltenberg|first3=Randall M.|last4=Chen|first4=Christopher V. H-H.|last5=Barman|first5=Soumendra|last6=Muir|first6=Beinn V. O.|last7=Sokolov|first7=Anatoliy N.|last8=Reese|first8=Colin|last9=Bao|first9=Zhenan|date=October 2010|title=Highly sensitive flexible pressure sensors with microstructured rubber dielectric layers|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nmat2834|journal=Nature Materials|language=En|volume=9|issue=10|pages=859–864|doi=10.1038/nmat2834|issn=1476-4660}}</ref> Microstructured polydimethylsiloxane thin films can elastically deform when pressure is applied. The deformation of the thin film allows for storage and release of energy.<ref name=":11" />
Visual representation of applied pressure has been one area of interest in development of tactile sensors.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Wang|first=Chuan|last2=Hwang|first2=David|last3=Yu|first3=Zhibin|last4=Takei|first4=Kuniharu|last5=Park|first5=Junwoo|last6=Chen|first6=Teresa|last7=Ma|first7=Biwu|last8=Javey|first8=Ali|date=October 2013|title=User-interactive electronic skin for instantaneous pressure visualization|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/nmat3711|journal=Nature Materials|language=En|volume=12|issue=10|pages=899–904|doi=10.1038/nmat3711|issn=1476-4660}}</ref> The Bao Group at Stanford University have designed an electrochromically active electronic skin that changes color with different amounts of applied pressure.<ref name=":1" /> Applied pressure can also be visualized by incorporation of active-matrix organic light-emitting diode displays which emit light when pressure is applied.<ref name=":12" />
===Other sensing applications=== Humidity sensors have been incorporated in electronic skin design with sulfurized tungsten films. The conductivity of the film changes with different levels of humidity.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Guo|first=Huayang|last2=Lan|first2=Changyong|last3=Zhou|first3=Zhifei|last4=Sun|first4=Peihua|last5=Wei|first5=Dapeng|last6=Li|first6=Chun|date=2017-05-18|title=Transparent, flexible, and stretchable WS2 based humidity sensors for electronic skin|url=http://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=C7NR01016H|journal=Nanoscale|language=en|volume=9|issue=19|pages=6246–6253|doi=10.1039/c7nr01016h|issn=2040-3372}}</ref> Silicon nanoribbons have also been studied for their application as temperature, pressure, and humidity sensors.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kim|first=Jaemin|last2=Lee|first2=Mincheol|last3=Shim|first3=Hyung Joon|last4=Ghaffari|first4=Roozbeh|last5=Cho|first5=Hye Rim|last6=Son|first6=Donghee|last7=Jung|first7=Yei Hwan|last8=Soh|first8=Min|last9=Choi|first9=Changsoon|date=2014-12-09|title=Stretchable silicon nanoribbon electronics for skin prosthesis|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms6747|journal=Nature Communications|language=En|volume=5|pages=5747|doi=10.1038/ncomms6747}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Artificial cell]] *[[Artificial muscle]] *[[Electronic nose]] *[[Electronic tongue]] *[[Sensitive skin (electronic device)|Sensitive skin]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Emerging technologies]] [[Category:Robotic sensing]] [[Category:Smart materials]] [[Category:Synthetic biology]]

'''Emily Howell''' is a computer program created by [[David Cope]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2010/jul/11/david-cope-computer-composer|title=David Cope: 'You pushed the button and out came hundreds and thousands of sonatas'|last=Adams|first=Tim|date=2010-07-10|work=The Observer|access-date=2017-10-06|language=en-GB|issn=0029-7712}}</ref> a music professor at the [[University of California, Santa Cruz]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/music-news/6404737/Emily-Howell-the-computer-program-that-composes-classical-music.html|title=Emily Howell: the computer program that composes classical music|last=Leach|first=Ben|date=2009-10-22|access-date=2017-10-06|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref><ref name="Ars Technica">{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2009/09/virtual-composer-makes-beautiful-musicand-stirs-controversy/|title=Virtual Composer Makes Beautiful Music and Stirs Controversy|first=Jacqui|last=Cheng|publisher=Ars Technica}}</ref> Emily Howell is an interactive interface that "hears" feedback from listeners, and builds its own musical compositions from a source database, derived from a previous composing program called '''Experiments in Musical Intelligence (EMI)'''.<ref>[[David Cope]] (1987), "Experiments in Music Intelligence." In Proceedings of the International Computer Music Conference, San Francisco: Computer Music Assn.</ref> Cope attempts to “teach” the program by providing feedback so that it can cultivate its own "personal" style.<ref name="Ars Technica"/> The software appears to be based on [[latent semantic analysis]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wiggins|first=G. A.|title=Computer Models of Musical Creativity: A Review of Computer Models of Musical Creativity by David Cope|journal=Literary and Linguistic Computing|date=14 December 2007|volume=23|issue=1|pages=109–116|doi=10.1093/llc/fqm025|url=http://yaxu.org/tmp/wiggins-cope.pdf}}</ref>
Emily Howell’s first album<ref>http://www.centaurrecords.com/store/emily-howell-from-darkness-light-music-composed-by-a-computer-program-designed-by-david-cope-from-darkness-light.html</ref> was released in February 2009 by [[Centaur Records]] (CRC 3023). Titled ''From Darkness, Light'', this album contains her Opus 1, Opus 2, and Opus 3 compositions for chamber orchestra and multiple pianos. Her second album ''Breathless'' was released in December 2012 by Centaur Records (CRC 3255).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nextnature.net/2015/03/artificial-intelligence-able-to-create-music/|title=Artificial Intelligence Able to Create Music|date=2015-03-21|work=Next Nature Network|access-date=2017-10-06|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>http://www.centaurrecords.com/store/emily-howell-breathless-silver-blood.html</ref>
== See also == * [[List of music software]] * [[Music and artificial intelligence]] * [[Computer music]] * [[Sonification]]
== References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist|30em}}
* Computer Models of Musical Creativity, MIT Press (December 16, 2005), {{ISBN|0262033380}}
== External links == *http://artsites.ucsc.edu/faculty/cope/experiments.htm *http://www.news.com.au/national/meet-emily-howell-classical-musics-virtual-composer/story-e6frfkp9-1225789839139
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Artificial intelligence]] [[Category:Computer music software]] [[Category:Computer-related introductions in 2009]] [[Category:University of California, Santa Cruz]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{More footnotes|date=October 2010}} {{Infobox economist | name = Evan Durbin | honorific_suffix = {{postnom|size=100|country=GBR|MP}} | school_tradition = [[Market socialism]]
| image = Evan Durbin.jpg | image_size = | caption = Durbin, {{c.|1930s}} | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1906|03|01}} | birth_place = [[Bideford]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1948|09|03|1906|03|01}} | death_place = [[Crackington Haven]] | nationality = British | institution = [[London School of Economics]] | field = [[Macroeconomics]] | alma_mater = {{ubl|[[New College, Oxford]]|[[Taunton School]]|[[Hele's School, Exeter]]}} | influences = {{hlist|[[Lionel Robbins]]|[[Reginald Bassett]]|[[G. D. H. Cole]]|[[R. H. Tawney]]|[[James Meade]]|[[John Bowlby]]|[[Solly Zuckerman]]|Susan Isaacs{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}}} | influenced = [[Hugh Gaitskell]], [[Anthony Crosland]] | contributions = | awards = | signature = <!-- file name only --> | repec_prefix = | repec_id = }} '''Evan Frank Mottram Durbin''' (1 March 1906 – 3 September 1948)<ref>{{Rayment-hc|e|1|date=March 2012}}</ref> was a British economist and [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] politician, whose writings combined a belief in central [[economic planning]] with a conviction that the price mechanism of markets was indispensable.
Historian [[David Kynaston]] described Durbin as "the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]]'s most interesting thinker of the 1940s and arguably of the twentieth century".
== Early life == Durbin was born in 1906, the son of a Baptist minister. He was educated at Plympton and Exmouth Elementary Schools; [[Hele's School, Exeter|Heles School, Exeter]]; [[Taunton School]]; and [[New College, Oxford]]. At Oxford he studied zoology, followed by PPE, and became one of what Ben Pimlott described as 'the "Cole group" of distinguished young socialists'.<ref name="Pimlott">Pimlott, Ben "Harold Wilson" Harper Collins (1993).</ref>{{rp|67}} He befriended [[Hugh Gaitskell]] (later, leader of the Labour Party 1955–63) during the General Strike of 1926, when he undertook public speaking tasks on behalf of the strikers in and around Oxford, and Gaitskell acted as his driver.<ref name="Williams">Williams, Philip M. "Hugh Gaitskell" OUP (1982).</ref>{{rp|22}} In 1929, he was awarded a Ricardo scholarship to study economics at [[University College London|University College, London]], where Gaitskell was already on the teaching staff<ref name="Williams"/>{{rp|39–40}} and their friendship, which lasted until Durbin's death, cemented itself.
== Economic career == In autumn 1930 he was appointed to a lectureship in economics at the [[London School of Economics]] (LSE), where he remained until 1940. Lecturer and Senior Lecturer in Economics, London School of Economics, 1930–1945.
== Political career == Politically, Durbin defined himself as a 'militant Moderate'.
In [[United Kingdom general election, 1931|1931]] he was the unsuccessful Labour Parliamentary candidate for [[East Grinstead (UK Parliament constituency)|East Grinstead]], where Gaitskell spoke for him, addressing a meeting which included 'rowdy but good-natured Tory opposition',<ref>Gaitskell, H, Preface to "The Politics of Democratic Socialism" by Evan Durbin (Routledge, 1940)</ref> and in [[United Kingdom general election, 1935|1935]] he stood for [[Gillingham (UK Parliament constituency)|Gillingham, Kent]], where, in his selection speech, Durbin famously prioritised the preservation of political democracy over the pursuit of both socialism and peace.<ref name="Williams"/>{{rp|47}}
In early 1939 he joined with [[Douglas Jay, Baron Jay|Douglas Jay]] and Hugh Gaitskell in urging the Labour Party leadership to agree to the government's proposal for military conscription, so long as there was a ''quid pro quo'' in the form of '"conscription of wealth" (a wealth tax).<ref>McDermott, Geoffrey; "Leader Lost" Leslie Frewin (1972) p. 22</ref> Instead, the Labour Party refused to support conscription at all. Once war was declared, Durbin was temporarily seconded to the Economic Section of the War Cabinet Secretariat, with other notable economists such as [[Lionel Robbins]] and the young [[Harold Wilson]],<ref name="Pimlott"/>{{rp|73}} 1940–1942 (during which time he penned ''The Politics of Democratic Socialism'', described by Professor David Marquand as consummating "[t]he marriage between Keynsianism and Fabianism"<ref>Marquand, David "The Progressive Dilemma" Phoenix Giant (1989) at p. 56</ref>); and then was temporary Personal Assistant to [[Clement Attlee]], Deputy Prime Minister, 1942–1945.
Durbin was elected Labour MP for [[Edmonton (UK Parliament constituency)|Edmonton]] in [[United Kingdom general election, 1945|1945]], and was amongst those invited to [[Hugh Dalton]]'s "Young Victors' Dinner", held at [[St Ermin's Hotel]], off Victoria Street SW1. As other guests included George Brown, [[Richard Crossman]], John Freeman, Hugh Gaitskell, Harold Wilson and [[Woodrow Wyatt]],<ref name="Pimlott"/>{{rp|93}} it is fairly clear that Durbin was regarded as a man of the future. He was Dalton's Parliamentary Private Secretary from 1945–47,<ref name="Pimlott"/>{{rp|95}} and started a ministerial career as Parliamentary Secretary, Ministry of Works, 1947–1948.
On 2 September 1948 Durbin drowned while rescuing one of his daughters from the sea at Strangles Beach, south of [[Bude]], on the coast of [[Cornwall]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Austerity Britain, 1945–1951 |last=Kynaston |first=David |authorlink=David Kynaston |year=2007 |publisher=[[Bloomsbury Publishing|Bloomsbury]] |location=London |isbn=978-0-7475-9923-4 |page=295}}</ref>
== Legacy == Writing in ''The Times'' after Durbin's death, Hugh Gaitskell paid tribute to Durbin's 'clarity of purpose' and 'well defined set of moral values and social ideals'. Gaitskell wrote that Durbin 'insisted in applying the process of reasoning unflinchingly and with complete intellectual integrity to all human problems' – including a consistent opposition to the dictatorship of Stalin, for 'he would not sentimentalise about tyranny, which seemed to him equally odious everywhere'. Gaitskell noted in his diary: "There is ... nobody else in my life whom I can consult on the most fundamental issues, knowing that I shall get the guidance I want".<ref name="Williams"/>{{rp|129}}
Despite his early death, Durbin continued to influence on Labour Party thinking throughout the 1950s, particularly for Gaitskell (who became party leader in 1955) and Labour revisionist [[Anthony Crosland]].
Durbin was also an influence on the founders of the [[Social Democratic Party]] (SDP) in 1981. For the SDP, Durbin's writing provided a model for a successful fight against the left within the Labour Party.
== Publications == * ''Purchasing Power and Trade Depression: a critique of under-consumption theories'' (Jonathan Cape, London and Toronto, 1933) * ''Socialist Credit Policy'' (Victor Gollancz, London, 1934) * ''The Problem of Credit Policy'' (Chapman and Hall, London, 1935) * (Editor) ''War and Democracy: essays on the causes and prevention of war'' (Kegan Paul and Co, London, 1938) * ''[[How to Pay for the War]]'' (G Routledge and Sons, London, 1939) * ''Personal Aggressiveness and War'' (Kegan Paul and Co, London, 1939) * ''The Politics of Democratic Socialism'' (G. Routledge and Sons, London, 1940) * ''What Have we to Defend? A brief critical examination of the British social tradition'' (G. Routledge and Sons, London, 1942) * ''Problems of Economic Planning'' (Routledge and Kegan Paul, London, 1949)
== References == {{reflist}}
== Sources == * Catherine Ellis: [http://www.oxforddnb.com/index/39/101039462/ Biography of Evan Durbin] from ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', 2004 * ''Times Guide to the House of Commons'', 1945
==External links== * {{Hansard-contribs | mr-evan-durbin | Evan Durbin }} * [http://archives.lse.ac.uk/TreeBrowse.aspx?src=CalmView.Catalog&field=RefNo&key=DURBIN Catalogue of the Durbin papers at LSE Archives]
