revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox Politician (general) |image = Thomas Noguchi at the American Academy of Forensic Sciences Las Vegas conference 2016.jpg |imagesize = | caption = Thomas Noguchi at the AAFS 2016 conference at Las Vegas | name = Thomas Noguchi
野口恒富 |birth_name=Thomas Tsunetomi Noguchi | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1927|1|4}} | birth_place = [[Japan]] | death_date = | death_place = | restingplace = | nationality = [[United States|American]] | occupation = [[Coroner]], medical examiner | residence = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] | alma_mater = [[Nippon Medical School]] | title = [[Los Angeles County Coroner|Chief Medical Examiner-Coroner for the County of Los Angeles]] | term_start = 1967 | term_end = 1982 | predecessor = [[Theodore Curphey]] | successor = [[Ronald Kornblum]] }} {{nihongo|'''Thomas Tsunetomi Noguchi'''|野口 恒富|Noguchi Tsunetomi|extra=born January 4, 1927}} is a former Chief [[Medical Examiner]]-[[Coroner]] for the [[County of Los Angeles]], who served in that position from 1967 to 1982. Known as the "coroner to the stars", he determined the cause of death in many high-profile cases during the 1960s and 1970s. He is most famous for performing autopsies on [[Marilyn Monroe]], [[Robert F. Kennedy]], [[Sharon Tate]], [[Gia Scala]], [[William Holden]], [[Natalie Wood]], and [[John Belushi]]. ==Career== Noguchi was born in Japan and graduated from [[Tokyo]]'s [[Nippon Medical School]] in 1951 before interning at The [[University of Tokyo]] School of Medicine Hospital.{{cite web |last1=Robert |first1=Lindsey |title=MAN IN THE NEWS; A CHASTISED 'CORNER TO THE STARS' |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/12/us/man-in-the-news-a-chastised-corner-to-the-stars.html |date=March 12, 1982 |website=The New York Times |publisher=Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Sr. |accessdate=31 October 2018}} Shortly thereafter he immigrated to the United States. He then served a second internship at Orange County General Hospital and a series of residencies at [[Loma Linda University]] School of Medicine, and Barlow Sanatorium in Los Angeles.{{cite web |title=Thomas T. Noguchi Receives the R.B.H. Gradwohl Medallion |date=April 2, 2015 |url=https://news.aafs.org/aafs-news/thomas-t-noguchi-receives-the-r-b-h-gradwohl-medallion/ |website=American Academy of Forensic Sciences |accessdate=31 October 2018}} He was appointed a deputy coroner for [[Los Angeles County]] in 1961. In 1967, he became Chief Medical Examiner (CME) for the county, replacing his mentor [[Theodore Curphey]]. As CME, Noguchi came to public attention for a series of [[Autopsy|autopsies]]; which he performed or supervised on a range of celebrities and public figures that included [[Albert Dekker]], [[Robert F. Kennedy]], [[Sharon Tate]], [[Janis Joplin]], [[Inger Stevens]], [[Gia Scala]], [[David Janssen]], [[William Holden]], [[Natalie Wood]], and [[John Belushi]]. His autopsy of Kennedy is significant for its conclusion that the fatal shot was fired into the back of Kennedy's head, behind the right ear, from an upward angle, and from a distance of no more than 0.5 to 3 inches (15–75 mm) away. Such a finding has given rise to [[Robert F. Kennedy assassination#Alternative theories|conspiracy theories regarding the assassination]], as no witnesses reported seeing the convicted assassin, [[Sirhan Sirhan]], in a position to fire such a shot. Noguchi himself points out in his memoir ''Coroner'' that he has never officially ruled that Sirhan fired the fatal shot.[http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/terrorists_spies/assassins/kennedy/5.html truTV Crime Library: The Assassination of Robert F. Kennedy] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090515193618/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/terrorists_spies/assassins/kennedy/5.html |date=May 15, 2009 }} He developed a high profile as CME, and was often accused of speaking too freely to the media, particularly following the November 1981 deaths of [[William Holden]] and [[Natalie Wood]], which, along with moonlighting and alleged mismanagement, led to his demotion from coroner to physician specialist in 1982.{{cite news|title=Noguchi Begins New Job|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19820429&id=ZoZhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bOQFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6580,5716558|accessdate=October 16, 2013|newspaper=Reading Eagle|date=April 29, 1982}} He was later appointed Chief of Pathology at the [[University of Southern California]] and then as Administrative Pathologist for Anatomic Pathology services at the [[Los Angeles County-USC Medical Center|USC Medical Center]]. Noguchi was appointed professor by both the University of Southern California and [[University of California in Los Angeles|UCLA]]. He is a past president of the American National Association of Medical Examiners. In 1999 he was honored by the [[Emperor of Japan]] who awarded him the [[Order of the Sacred Treasure]] for his "outstanding contributions to Japan in the area of [[forensic science]]".[http://www.duq.edu/forensics/advisory-board/noguchi.cfm Duquesne/Wecht Institute of Forensic Science and Law -- bio] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716110807/http://www.duq.edu/forensics/advisory-board/noguchi.cfm |date=July 16, 2011 }} He retired the same year. {{As of|2017}}, Noguchi is the president of World Association for Medical Law (WAML), which is a medical body founded in 1967 to encourage the study of [[health law]], [[Medical jurisprudence|legal medicine]], and [[bioethics]].[http://wafml.memberlodge.org/page-1046309 World Association for Medical Law Executive Committee], accessed August 18, 2017. ==Publications== *''Coroner'', 1983. A best selling memoir written with Joseph DiMona. (Published in the UK as ''Coroner to the Stars'') *''Coroner at Large'' 1985. A book about historical coroners and famous deaths. ([https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A0DE2DB113AF930A15751C0A960948260 NYT review.]) *''Unnatural Causes'', 1988. A detective novel written with Arthur Lyons. *''Physical Evidence'', 1990. A detective novel written with Arthur Lyons. ==Film and other media== * He has appeared in the documentary ''[[The Killing of America]]'' (1982). * He appeared as himself in the film ''[[Faces of Death]]'' (1980). * In 2000, Noguchi appeared in Michael Kriegsman's autopsy-related documentaries, "Autopsy: Through the Eyes of Death's Detectives"; and "Autopsy: Voices of Death", wherein Noguchi takes the viewer through a complete autopsy. * He is said to have been the inspiration for the TV series ''[[Quincy, M.E.]]'' (1976–1983), which starred [[Jack Klugman]].[http://www.who2.com/thomasnoguchi.html Thomas Noguchi] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=634027}} * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030215020505/http://www.omnimag.com/archives/interviews/noguchi.html |date=February 15, 2003 |title=1986 interview }} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060524065631/http://www-hsc.usc.edu/~noguchi/ Subject's USC web page, last updated in 1999] {{County of Los Angeles}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Noguchi, Thomas}} [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Writers from Los Angeles]] [[Category:Japanese emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:American people of Japanese descent]] [[Category:American coroners]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Sacred Treasure]] [[Category:University of Southern California faculty]] [[Category:University of California, Los Angeles faculty]] [[Category:Persons involved with death and dying]] [[Category:Physicians from California]] [[Category:American physicians of Japanese descent]]

{{about|the mission|the rocket|Vostok-2 (rocket)}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = Vostok 2 | image = Vostok_spacecraft.jpg | image_caption = Model of the Vostok capsule with its upper stage | insignia = Vostok2patch.png | mission_type = | operator = [[Soviet space program]] | Harvard_designation = 1961 Tau 1 | SATCAT = 168 | mission_duration = 1 day, 1 hour, 18 minutes | orbits_completed = 17.5 | distance_travelled = | spacecraft = [[Vostok (spacecraft)|Vostok-3KA]] No.4 | manufacturer = Experimental Design [[OKB-1]] | launch_mass = {{convert|4731|kg|lb}}{{cite journal |date=17 August 1961|title=The First Day In Orbit |journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |issue=2736 |volume=80 |page=208 |publisher=Iliffe Transport Publications |location=London |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1961/1961%20-%201106.html |format=PDF |accessdate=2009-03-12}} | landing_mass = | launch_date = {{start-date|August 6, 1961, 06:00|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Vostok-K]] 8K72K | launch_site = [[Baikonur Cosmodrome|Baikonur]] [[Baikonur Cosmodrome Site 1|1/5]]{{cite web |url=http://www.astronautix.com/sites/baiurlc1.htm |title=Baikonur LC1 |accessdate=2009-03-04 |work=[[Encyclopedia Astronautica]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090415160730/http://www.astronautix.com/sites/baiurlc1.htm |archivedate=2009-04-15 |df= }} | landing_date = {{end-date|August 7, 1961, 07:18|timezone=yes}} UTC | landing_site = [[Krasny Kut, Saratov Oblast|Krasny Kut]]
{{coord|50.85276|N|47.02048|E}}{{cite web|url = https://maps.google.com/maps?ll=50.85375,47.021334&spn=0.006651,0.02075&t=k&z=16&iwloc=lyrftr:com.panoramio.all,1711661006741655857,50.852287,47.020454&lci=com.panoramio.all|title = Google Maps - Vostok 2 Landing Site - Monument|accessdate = 2010-12-25}} | orbit_epoch = {{date|1961-08-06}}, 02:00:00 UTC{{Cite web|url=https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftOrbit.do?id=1961-019A|title=NASA - NSSDCA - Spacecraft - Trajectory Details|website=nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov|access-date=2018-05-02}} | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[low Earth orbit|Low Earth]] | orbit_eccentricity = 0.00501 | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|166|km|mi}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|232|km|mi}}{{cite journal |date=21 September 1961|title=Missiles and Spaceflight |issue=2741 |journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |volume=80 |page=467 |publisher=Iliffe Transport Publications |location=London |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1961/1961%20-%201363.html |format=PDF |accessdate=2009-03-12}} | orbit_inclination = 64.93 degrees | orbit_period = 88.46 minutes | apsis = gee | crew_size = 1 | crew_members = [[Gherman Titov]] | crew_callsign = {{lang|ru|Орёл}} ({{lang|ru-Latn|Oryol}} - "Eagle") | crew_photo = Gherman Titov 2.jpg | crew_photo_caption = | previous_mission = [[Vostok 1]] | next_mission = [[Vostok 3]] | programme = [[Vostok programme]]
Manned flights }} '''Vostok 2''' ({{lang-ru|'''Восток-2'''}}, ''[[Orient]] 2'' or ''East 2'') was a [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] space mission which carried [[astronaut|cosmonaut]] [[Gherman Titov]] into orbit for a full day on August 6, 1961 to study the effects of a more prolonged period of [[weightlessness]] on the human body. Titov orbited the Earth over 17 times, exceeding the single orbit of [[Yuri Gagarin]] on [[Vostok 1]] − as well as the suborbital spaceflights of [[United States of America|American]] astronauts [[Alan Shepard]] and [[Gus Grissom]] aboard their respective [[Mercury-Redstone 3]] and [[Mercury-Redstone 4|4]] missions. Indeed, Titov's number of orbits and flight time would not be surpassed by an American astronaut until [[Gordon Cooper|Gordon Cooper's]] [[Mercury-Atlas 9]] spaceflight in May 1963. After the flight of Vostok 1, [[Sergei Korolev]] took a short vacation in Crimea where he began working out the flight plan for the next mission. There were considerable arguments over the duration of the mission as flight doctors argued for no more than three orbits. The flight of [[Korabl-Sputnik 2]] nine months earlier had carried two dogs on a six orbit mission, during which the animals had experienced convulsions and thus all subsequent Vostok missions were limited to three orbits maximum. Although dogs and humans were very different physiologically, the doctors were worried about the risks posed on a longer flight. There was also the purely practical aspect of spacecraft recovery. If Vostok 2 flew three orbits, reentry and landing would take place in the wide open steppes of southern Russia, the landing site moving steadily further west with each orbit. Orbits 8-13 would drop the capsule into the [[Pacific Ocean]], after which landing would again occur in Soviet territory, but in the remote, frozen wastes of [[Siberia]]. Thus, it was necessary to spend a full 24 hours in space before it would be once again possible to land in the prime recovery area in southern Russia. The three orbit limit thus would not only make landing easy, but minimize risks to the cosmonaut posed by prolonged weightlessness. Korolev argued that since it would still take an entire day for landing in southern Russia to be possible again, there was no reason not to go for it. Besides, he argued, missions of the future would inevitably require lengthy stays in space. The flight was targeted for somewhere between July 25 and August 5. To ensure safe radiation levels, balloons equipped with [[Geiger counter]]s were flown aloft, in addition similar equipment would be carried on Vostok 2. Several enhancements were made to Vostok 2, including an improved TV transmission system and better climate control systems. Liftoff took place August 6 at 8:57 AM Moscow time and booster performance was almost flawless, placing the spacecraft into a 184x244 km orbit. The flight was an almost complete success, marred only by a heater that had inadvertently been turned off prior to liftoff and that allowed the inside temperature to drop to {{convert|50|°F|°C}},{{cite book |title=[[Into That Silent Sea|Into That Silent Sea: Trailblazers of the Space Era, 1961-1965]] |year=2007 |publisher=University of Nebraska Press |location=Lincoln, Nebr. |isbn= 978-0-8032-1146-9 |oclc=71210133 |author= [[Francis French]]; [[Colin Burgess (author)|Colin Burgess]]}}{{rp|113}} a bout of [[space sickness]], and a troublesome re-entry when the [[reentry module]] failed to separate cleanly from its [[service module]].{{cite web |url=http://www.svengrahn.pp.se/histind/Vostok2/vostok2.html |title=The flight of Vostok-2 |accessdate=2009-03-12 |last=Grahn |first=Sven |work=Sven's Space Place}} Unlike Yuri Gagarin on Vostok 1, Titov took manual control of the spacecraft for a short while. Another change came when the Soviets admitted that Titov did not land with his spacecraft. Titov would claim in an interview that he ejected from his capsule as a test of an alternative landing system; it is now known that all [[Vostok program]] landings were performed this way.{{cite journal |author1=Ezell, Edward Clinton |author2=Ezell, Linda Neuman |year=1978 |title=The Partnership: A History of the Apollo-Soyuz Test Project |journal=NASA History Series |issue=NASA Special Publication-4209 |publisher=NASA |url=https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4209/ch3-4.htm |accessdate=2009-03-17|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070823124845/https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4209/ch3-4.htm|archivedate=2007-08-23}} The re-entry capsule was destroyed during development of the [[Voskhod spacecraft]].{{rp|117}} As of 2017, Titov remains the youngest person to reach space. He was a month short of 26 years old at launch.{{cite web |url=http://www.astronautix.com/articles/aststics.htm |title=Astronaut Statistics |accessdate=2009-03-12 |last=Wade |first=Mark |work=[[Encyclopedia Astronautica]]}} ==Crew== {{Spaceflight crew |terminology = Cosmonaut |position1 = Pilot |crew1_up = [[Gherman Titov]] |flights1_up = Only }} ===Backup crew=== {{Spaceflight crew |terminology = Cosmonaut |position1 = Pilot |crew1_up = [[Andrian Nikolayev|Andrian G. Nikolayev]] }} ===Reserve crew=== {{Spaceflight crew |terminology = Cosmonaut |position1 = Pilot |crew1_up = [[Grigori Nelyubov]] }} ==Mission parameters== *'''[[Mass]]:''' {{convert|4731|kg|lb|abbr=on}} *'''[[Perigee]]:''' {{convert|183|km|mi|abbr=on}} *'''[[Apogee]]:''' {{convert|244|km|mi|abbr=on}} *'''[[Inclination]]:''' 64.93° *'''[[Orbital period|Period]]:''' 88.46 minutes ==Mission highlights== Gherman Titov launched from [[Gagarin's Start]] at [[Baikonur Cosmodrome]] on 6 August 1961 at 06:00 UTC aboard the Vostok 2 [[space capsule]]. Radio personality [[Yuri Levitan]] interrupted [[Radio Moscow]] programming with an announcement of the flight at 07:45 UTC. Nausea set in after Titov achieved [[weightlessness|free fall]] in orbit, causing him to vomit when he tried to eat one of his planned meals. Soviet space program officials suspected disturbance of Titov's [[vestibular system]] was to blame, leading them to begin early investigations into what is now known as [[space adaptation syndrome]], or space sickness. Titov is believed to be the first spacefarer to experience the condition.{{cite journal |date=6 September 1962|title="Group Space Flight" Described − Part 2 |journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |issue=2791 |volume=82 |pages=389–391 |publisher=Iliffe Transport Publications |location=London |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1962/1962%20-%201887.html |format=PDF |accessdate=2009-03-17}}{{cite book |last1=Oman |first1=Charles M. |last2=Lichtenburg |first2=Byron K. |last3=Money |first3=Kenneth E. |editor-last=Crampton |editor-first=George |title=Motion and Space Sickness |edition=illustrated |date=17 January 1990 |publisher=CRC Press |isbn=0-8493-4703-3 |page=218 |chapter=Symptoms and Signs of Space Motion Sickness on SPACELAB-1}} [[Image:Vostok2-Pin.jpg|left|thumb|Commemorative pin from Vostok 2 Mission]]Titov took manual control of the capsule's [[attitude dynamics and control|attitude]] for a time as he passed over Africa on his first orbit and would again at the end of the seventh orbit; the controls were reported to function well. Titov exchanged greetings with Soviet Premier [[Nikita Khrushchev]] as he passed over the Soviet Union at the end of his first orbit, replicating Gagarin's feat. During his flight the first manual photographs were taken from orbit, thus setting a record for modern [[space photography]]. He also was the first person to film the Earth using, for ten minutes, a professional quality Konvas-Avtomat movie camera.{{cite web|url= http://www.astronautix.com/astros/titov.htm |publisher= Encyclopedia Astronautica |title= Titov |accessdate= 18 February 2014 }}{{cite web|url= http://www.postiar.com/post/24107/the-first-pictures-of-earth-marks-50-years.html |title= The first pictures of Earth marks 50 years |accessdate= 18 February 2014 }} A camera aboard the capsule transmitted smiling pictures of Titov to the ground as he passed over Soviet territory on the fifth orbit. Titov settled down to sleep during the seventh orbit; he awoke over eight hours later, 37 minutes after the scheduled end of his sleep period. Sleep did not relieve Titov's serious discomfort; he still felt very ill after awaking. After 12 orbits Titov suddenly began to recover, and became "completely functional and fully fit".{{cite book | last = Siddiqi | first = Asif A. | url = https://history.nasa.gov/printFriendly/series95.html | title = Challenge To Apollo: The Soviet Union and the Space Race, 1945-1974 | publisher = [[NASA]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061008193942/https://history.nasa.gov/printFriendly/series95.html|archivedate=2006-10-08}}{{rp|293–294}} Detailed information about the radio frequencies used by the spacecraft were made public before Titov's flight; listening posts around the world picked up voice and telemetry signals from Vostok 2, allaying suspicions that the spaceflight might have been faked. As on Vostok 1, the Vostok 2 service module failed to detach from the reentry module when commanded and [[Atmospheric reentry|reentry]] began with the former still attached; the conjoined modules gyrated violently until [[aerodynamic heating]] burned through the straps still holding them together. Titov ejected from the capsule as planned and parachuted separately to land at 0718 UTC on 7 August 1961, near [[Krasny Kut, Saratov Oblast]].Just prior to ejecting, Titov turned his head to look at something and so got his face rammed into his helmet at ejection, giving himself a bloody nose. The Vostok 2 landing site coordinates are {{coord|50.85276|N|47.02048|E}}, which is 11.5 km South of Krasny Kut, Saratovskaya oblast in the Russian Federation. At the roadside site are two monuments dedicated to the Vostok 2 mission. The larger one is a 9 meter tall, silver painted stone sculpture, that resembles a single bird's wing pointed skyward. The center of the wing has a series of looping openings, one atop the next, that resemble a row of feathers. To the right of the wing sculpture is a 2 meter high, silver painted square stone block, with a rounded corner on the front side. A portrait of Titov, wearing a space helmet, is on one side of the stone block, the other side contains red painted text commemorating the mission.{{cite web|url = https://maps.google.com/maps?t=h&lci=org.wikipedia.en&q=50.85276,47.02048(Vostok+2)&ie=UTF8&ll=50.852789,47.020562&spn=0.006651,0.020707&z=16 |title = Google Maps - Vostok 2 Landing Site - Monument Location|accessdate = 2010-12-27}}{{cite web|url = https://maps.google.com/maps?ll=50.85375,47.021334&spn=0.006651,0.020707&t=k&z=16&iwloc=lyrftr:com.panoramio.all,1711661006741655857,50.852287,47.020454&lci=com.panoramio.all |title = Google Maps - Vostok 2 Landing Site - Monument Photo|accessdate = 2010-12-27}}{{cite web|url = https://maps.google.com/maps?ll=50.852287,47.020454&spn=0,0.020707&t=k&z=16&lci=com.panoramio.all&layer=c&cbll=50.852287,47.020454&cbp=12,0,,0,5&photoid=po-3476203 |title = Google Maps - Vostok 2 Landing Site - Monument Photo closeup|accessdate = 2010-12-27}} In 1964, the Vostok 2 capsule was reused as a ballast weight in a test of an experimental parachute system planned for the ''Voskhod'' capsule. The prototype malfunctioned, shattering Vostok 2 into tiny pieces.{{rp|117}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Portal|Spaceflight|Soviet Union}} {{Vostok Programme}} {{Orbital launches in 1961}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1961]] [[Category:1961 in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Human spaceflights]] [[Category:Vostok program]] [[Category:Spacecraft which reentered in 1961]] [[Category:August 1961 events]]

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = Vostok 6 | image = Vostok 6 capsule on display, 2016.jpg | image_caption = The Vostok 6 capsule in a museum display (2016) | insignia = | mission_type = | operator = [[Soviet space program]] | COSPAR_ID = 1963-023A | SATCAT = 595 | mission_duration = 2 days, 22 hours, 50 minutes | orbits_completed = 48 | spacecraft = [[Vostok (spacecraft)|Vostok-3KA]] No.8 | manufacturer = Experimental Design Bureau [[OKB-1]] | launch_mass = {{convert|4713|kg|lb}} | landing_mass = | launch_date = {{start-date|16 June 1963, 09:29:52|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Vostok-K]] 8K72K | launch_site = [[Baikonur Cosmodrome|Baikonur]] [[Baikonur Cosmodrome Site 1|1/5]]{{cite web |url=http://www.astronautix.com/sites/baiurlc1.htm |title=Baikonur LC1 |accessdate=2009-03-30 |work=[[Encyclopedia Astronautica]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090415160730/http://www.astronautix.com/sites/baiurlc1.htm |archivedate=2009-04-15 |df= }} | landing_date = {{end-date|19 June 1963, 08:20|timezone=yes}} UTC | landing_site = {{coord|53.209375|N|80.80395|E}}{{cite web|url = https://maps.google.com/maps?t=h&lci=org.wikipedia.en&q=53.209375,80.80395(Vostok+6)&ie=UTF8&ll=53.209342,80.803944&spn=0.001539,0.004324&z=18|title = Google Maps - Vostok 6 Landing Site - Monument Location|accessdate = 2010-12-25}} | orbit_epoch = {{date|1963-06-16}}, 05:36:00 UTC{{Cite web|url=https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftOrbit.do?id=1963-023A|title=NASA - NSSDCA - Spacecraft - Trajectory Details|website=nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov|access-date=2018-05-02}} | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[low Earth orbit|Low Earth]] | orbit_eccentricity = 0.00365 | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|164|km|mi}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|212|km|mi}} | orbit_inclination = 65.09 degrees | orbit_period = 88.25 minutes | apsis = gee | crew_size = 1 | crew_members = [[Valentina Tereshkova]] | crew_callsign = {{lang|ru|Чайка}} ({{lang|ru-Latn|Chayka}} - "Seagull") | crew_photo = RIAN archive 612748 Valentina Tereshkova.jpg | crew_photo_caption = [[Valentina Tereshkova]], first female [[cosmonaut]], [[Hero of the Soviet Union]], 1969. | previous_mission = [[Vostok 5]] | programme = [[Vostok program]]
Manned flights }} '''Vostok 6''' ({{lang-ru|'''Восток-6'''}}, ''[[Orient]] 6'' or ''East 6'') was the first [[human spaceflight]] to carry a woman, [[astronaut|cosmonaut]] [[Valentina Tereshkova]], into space.{{Cite news|title = 1963: Soviets launch first woman into space|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/june/16/newsid_2685000/2685283.stm|newspaper = BBC|date = 1963-06-16|access-date = 2015-11-28}} ==Mission== The spacecraft was launched on June 16, 1963. While Vostok 5 had been delayed by technical problems, Vostok 6's launch proceeded with no difficulties. Data collected during the mission provided better understanding of the female body's reaction to spaceflight. Like other cosmonauts on Vostok missions, Tereshkova maintained a flight log, took photographs, and manually oriented the spacecraft. Her photographs of the horizon from space were later used to identify aerosol layers within the atmosphere. The mission, a joint flight with [[Vostok 5]], was originally conceived as being a joint mission with two Vostoks each carrying a female cosmonaut, but this changed as the Vostok program experienced cutbacks as a precursor to the retooling of the program into the [[Voskhod program]]. Vostok 6 was the last flight of a [[Vostok 3KA]] spacecraft. The Soviet state television network broadcast live video of Tereshkova from a camera inside the capsule, and she conversed with Premier [[Nikita Khrushchev]] over the radio. Communications with ground controllers about her overall health were described in post-flight reports as "evasive", and later official accounts of the mission had somewhat condescending remarks about Tereshkova's overall in-flight performance.{{cn|date=January 2018}} [[File:Radio Moscow announcement of Valentina Tereshkova space flight.ogg|thumb|[[Radio Moscow]] announces the historic flight of Tereshkova]] In Tereshkova's account of the mission in her postflight debriefing, she mentioned having assorted body pains and difficulty with her helmet headset (also reported by Bykovsky on Vostok 5). She vomited while attempting to eat, although she attributed this to the taste of the food rather than her physical condition.{{Cite web|title = Vostok 6|url = http://www.astronautix.com/flights/vostok6.htm|website = www.astronautix.com|accessdate = 2015-11-28|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131108102000/http://www.astronautix.com/flights/vostok6.htm|archivedate = 2013-11-08|df = }} An official history of the Soviet space program published in 1973 described Tereshkova's physical condition and in-flight performance as "udovletvoritelnoe" (adequate) rather than "otlichno" (good or outstanding).{{cn|date=January 2018}} It was revealed in 2004 that an error in the control program made the spaceship ascend from orbit instead of descending. Tereshkova noticed the fault on the first day of the flight and reported it to spaceship designer [[Sergey Korolev]]. Flight controllers then provided Tereshkova with data to enter into the descent program.{{cite web|url=http://www.kommersant.com/p-10235/Vostok-6_error/|title=World First Woman Cosmonaut Speaks About Error of Vostok Designers |work=Kommersant|date=2 March 2007|accessdate=2013-06-16|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070304081938/http://www.kommersant.com/p-10235/Vostok-6_error/|archivedate=4 March 2007}} By request of Korolev, Tereshkova kept the problem secret. "I kept silent, but [[Yevgeny Khrunov|Evgeny Vasilievich]] decided to make it public. So, I can easily talk about it now." The Vostok 6 landing site coordinates are {{Coord|53.209375|N|80.80395|E}}, 200 km West of [[Barnaul]], Altai, in the Russian Federation and 7 km south of Baevo, and 650 km North East of [[Karagandy]], [[Kazakhstan]]. At the site, in a small park at the roadside, is a statue of Tereshkova, with arms outstretched, at the top of a curved column.{{cite web|url = https://maps.google.com/maps?ll=53.209425,80.804427&spn=0,0.004324&t=k&z=18&lci=com.panoramio.all&layer=c&cbll=53.209425,80.804427&cbp=12,0,,0,5&photoid=po-25974536 |title = Google Maps – Vostok 6 Landing Site − Monument Photo closeup|accessdate = 2010-12-26}} The capsule is now on display at the [[RKK Energia Museum]] in [[Korolyov (city)|Korolyov]] (near [[Moscow]]). From September 2015 it formed part of the content of the "Cosmonauts" exhibition at the [[Science Museum, London]]. The Exhibition featured many iconic objects from the Soviet space program. This was the final [[Vostok spacecraft|Vostok]] flight. ==Crew== {{Spaceflight crew |terminology = Cosmonaut |position1 = Pilot |crew1_up = [[Valentina Tereshkova]] |flights1_up = First }} ===Backup crew=== {{Spaceflight crew |terminology = Cosmonaut |position1 = Pilot |crew1_up = [[Irina Solovyova]] }} ===Reserve crew=== {{Spaceflight crew |terminology = Cosmonaut |position1 = Pilot |crew1_up = [[Valentina Ponomaryova]] }} ==Mission parameters== * '''[[Mass]]:''' {{convert|4713|kg|lb|abbr=on}} * '''[[Apogee]]:''' {{convert|231|km|mi|abbr=on}} * '''[[Perigee]]:''' {{convert|180|km|mi|abbr=on}} * '''[[Inclination]]:''' 64.9° * '''[[Orbital period|Period]]:''' 87.8 minutes ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Spaceflight|Soviet Union}} {{Vostok Programme}} {{Orbital launches in 1963}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1963]] [[Category:1963 in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Valentina Tereshkova]] [[Category:Human spaceflights]] [[Category:Vostok program]] [[Category:Spacecraft which reentered in 1963]] [[Category:First events]] [[Category:June 1963 events]]

revision.text:
{{other uses|Worst-case scenario (disambiguation)}}
A '''worst-case scenario''' is a concept in [[risk management]] wherein the planner, in planning for potential [[disaster]]s, considers the most severe possible outcome that can reasonably be projected to occur in a given situation. Conceiving of worst-case scenarios is a common form of [[strategic planning]], specifically [[scenario planning]], to prepare for and minimize contingencies that could result in [[accident]]s, [[Quality assurance|quality]] problems, or other issues.
==Development and use== The worst-case scenario is "[o]ne of the most commonly used alternative scenarios".<ref name="Yoe">Charles Yoe, ''Principles of Risk Analysis: Decision Making Under Uncertainty'' (2011), p. 429-30.</ref> A [[risk manager]] may request "a conservative risk estimate representing a worst-case scenario" in order to determine the latitude they may exercise in planning steps to reduce risks.<ref name="Cheremisinoff">Nicholas P. Cheremisinoff, ''Environmental Technologies Handbook'' (2005), page 73-74.</ref> Generally, a worst-case scenario "is settled upon by agreeing that a given worst case is bad enough. However, it is important to recognize that no worst-case scenario is truly without potential nasty surprises".<ref name="Dewar">James A. Dewar, ''Assumption-Based Planning: A Tool for Reducing Avoidable Surprises'' (2002), p. 27.</ref> In other words, "[a] “worst-case scenario” is never the worst case",<ref>Alexander M. Ineichen, ''Asymmetric Returns: The Future of Active Asset Management'' (2011), Chapter 5.</ref> both because situations may arise that no planner could reasonably foresee,<ref name="Yoe"/> and because a given worst-case scenario is likely to consider only contingencies expected to arise in connection with a particular disaster. The worst-case scenario devised by a seismologist might be a particularly bad earthquake, and the worst-case scenario devised by a meteorologist might be a particularly bad hurricane, but it is unlikely that either of them will devise a scenario where a particularly bad storm occurs at the same time as a particularly bad earthquake.
The definition of a worst-case scenario varies by the field to which it is being applied. For example, in [[environmental engineering]]", "[a] worst-case scenario is defined as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a single vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint".<ref>Ashok Naimpally, Kirsten Rosselot, ''Environmental Engineering: Review for the Professional Engineering Examination'' (2013), p. 85.</ref> In this field, "[a]s in other fields, the worst-case scenario is a useful device when low probability events may result in a catastrophe that must be avoided even at great cost, but in most health risk assessments, a worst-case scenario is essentially a type of bounding estimate".<ref name="Cheremisinoff"/> In [[computer science]], the [[best, worst, and average case]] of a given algorithm express what the resource usage is at least, at most and on average, respectively. For many individuals, a worst case scenario is one that would result in their own death.<ref name="Annas">George J. Annas, ''Worst Case Bioethics: Death, Disaster, and Public Health'' (2010), p. xi-xii.</ref>
==Criticisms== A number of criticisms have been leveled against the use of worst-case scenarios.<ref name="Yoe"/> In some cases, a conceivable worst-case scenario within a field may be so far beyond the capacity of participants to deal with that it is not worth the effort to develop or explore such a scenario; where this is possible, it is "important to evaluate whether the development of a worst-case scenario is reasonable and desirable".<ref>Betty Biringer, Eric Vugrin, Drake Warren, ''Critical Infrastructure System Security and Resiliency'' (2013), p. 95.</ref> Entities that rely on such scenarios in planning may be led to plan too conservatively to take advantage of the usual absence of such scenarios, and may waste resources preparing for highly unlikely contingencies.<ref name="Yoe"/> At the extreme, it has been argued that the use of worst-case scenarios in disaster preparedness and training causes people to become conditioned to set aside ethical concerns and to over-react to lesser disasters.<ref name="Annas"/>
==See also== * [[Worst-Case Scenario series]], a series of books inspired by ''[[The Worst-Case Scenario Survival Handbook]]'', providing tips for surviving such scenarios * [[Worst-case complexity]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Risk management]] [[Category:Systems thinking]]

[[File:Zhang Yinwu.jpg|200px|right]] '''Zhang Yinwu''' ({{zh|張蔭梧}}); 1891 – May 27, 1949) was a [[Kuomintang]] educator and politician of the Republic of China. He was born in [[Baoding]], [[Hebei]]. He was a graduate of the [[Baoding Military Academy]]. He was the 17th Republican mayor of [[Beijing]]. After the capture of Beijing (called [[Beiping]] at the time) by the forces of the [[Communist Party of China]], he was arrested by the [[People's Liberation Army]] in February 1949 and jailed.
